Minister, will the Prime Minister allow a Queensland government to significantly weaken the national firearms agreement in the way proposed by One Nation and the Queensland National Party president? Can you, Minister, guarantee that the Prime Minister will not buckle on guns in order to appease the One Nation Party?

âThat question from Senator Bolkus is almost a gift to repeat the earlier answer. Senator Bolkus and almost every Australian who is vaguely interested in the national gun laws know the Prime Minister's commitment to these laws. They know that the Prime Minister is not prepared to see any watering down of these bills. In fact, it was largely at the Prime Minister's instigation that the Commonwealth's position was strengthened by amending the customs regulations recently.

answer.para: These gun laws are very much the creation of this Prime Minister. It was his leadership and determination that saw them come into being. His leadership and determination has not waned one millimetre.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Assistant Treasurer. The Assistant Treasurer's attention would have been drawn to recent newspaper reports highlighting the increasingly negative impact of the current taxation system on middle and low income earners. I ask: does the government plan to address the huge inequities and inefficiencies in our taxation system? In particular, will the minister outline the level and nature of support for fundamental reform of Australia's unfair tax system?

âThank you, Senator Crane, for that question. Senator Crane has a reputation in this chamber for always focussing on the main issues, and again his question on tax reform demonstrates that point. Yes, I have seen a number of newspaper reports highlighting problems with our current tax system. In fact, the front page of the Herald Sun today graphically illustrates how workers will be paying more and more in income tax unless something is done very soon to radically overhaul our tax system.

answer.para: The headline in the Herald Sun is: `The great tax grab', and the report goes on to say that workers face a huge tax grab. More than 2.4 million workers face being stranded on the top tax rate unless the system is radically overhauled, according to the Herald Sun. The report goes on to say:
New analysis of the tax system shows almost one in three workers will have been forced on to the top rate early in the new millennium.
The article also says:

Figures prepared for the Herald Sun by the Australian Taxpayers Association reveal that by 2003-4 more than 2.4 million workers will be paying 47 cents in the dollar, or 48.5 cents including the Medicare levy.

This and many other articles and studies have shown how our current tax system is hurting the average working Australian. Let me make it very clear: the government is strongly committed to fixing our unfair, outdated and inefficient tax system.
Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenators on my left will stop interjecting.

âWe are the only party prepared to take the necessary steps to overhaul our current tax system in this century and prepare it for the next. We are the only party prepared to seriously address the problems facing low and middle income earners.

answer.para: In relation to Senator Crane's question, I was pleased to read a recent quote by the shadow Treasurer, Mr Gary Evans. This is what he said. This goes a bit to the nub of Senator Crane's question. He said:
We can all agree that tax reform is a good thing.

I think we were pleased to hear that endorsement from the shadow Treasurer. We wait with great interest and eagerness to see just what the Labor Party has in mind on tax reform. That is becoming increasingly vague. He went on to say, somewhat surprisingly:
If we didn'tâie. if we weren't in favour of tax reformâwe would not have done so much of it ourselves in office.

I think the truth of the matter is that the Labor Party's idea of tax reform was more tax. Labor's tax reform in its last term meant putting up the following taxes. Let me list them. They increased the wholesale sales tax. They increased petrol excises.
Senator Conroy interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Conroy, stop shouting!

âThe Labor government increased the Medicare levy. The Labor government increased the company tax rate. They increased the fringe benefits tax, and they increased departure tax. Of course, above all they failed to deliver the l-a-w tax cuts. Labor had 13 years to make the tax system fairer, but they really fiddled and, while they fiddled, Rome burned and the tax system got worse and worse. (Time expired)

âMy question is directed to Senator Minchin, the Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister. Can the minister confirm that the constitutional provision for just terms compensation for Commonwealth acquisition of property rights applies equally to native title as it does to every right of every Australian? Has the government received any advice as to the amount of compensation payable should any federal government move to abolish the common law principle of native title property rights? Has the government received any advice as to the amount of compensation payable should a Queensland state government move to abolish native title? Who would be liable to pay this compensation? Would the Commonwealth provide financial assistance to Queensland for this purpose?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âI presume this question is motivated by the quite extraordinary proposition from One Nation that native title be completely extinguishedâa proposition which the coalition fundamentally and completely rejects as improper, unfair, unworkable and untenable.

answer.para: The government's advice is that native title should be regarded as a property right which, certainly at the federal level, would trigger the provisions in the constitution which require that any acquisition of property requires the Commonwealth to pay just terms compensation. That requirement is extended to the states by virtue of the operation of the Native Title Act, and this is as it should be.

Native title is and must be treated as a property right requiring full compensation for any acquisition of that property right. We have maintained those provisions in our amendments to the Native Title Act. Under our Native Title Amendment Bill, compensation on just terms is required for any non-discriminatory acquisition of native title. Certainly, with respect to Senator Chris Evans's question, the legal advice to the government is to that effect and we completely accept it.

The proposition that you can simply extinguish native title arbitrarily across the board could involve very significant compensation claims and, potentially, payments. One of the many reasons the coalition rejected the proposition that we should extinguish native title on pastoral leases following the Wik decision was that compensation could be quite significant. No-one is quite sure what appropriate just terms compensation is for the loss of native title and merely in the case of pastoral leases, which cover 40 per cent of Australia, that could be quite significant. If you were to, as the One Nation party suggests, extend extinguishment to the whole nation, involving the acquisition of what the Native Title Act treatsâand, we accept, properly treatsâas potentially the equivalent of freehold on vacant crown land, the compensation payments for the acquisition could be immense. Therefore, that proposition should be, and is, rejected out of hand by the coalition.

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Alston. The minister's attention would have been drawn to a propo sal by the Labor Party to quarantine Telstra's dividend into a special fund. Does this accord with the government's policy and what impact would alternative proposals have on Telstra should they be implemented? Would the minister inform the Senate how likely it is that under Labor the flow of dividends would continue to be available?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âSenator Boswell asked a very important question which arises out of a revelation on Channel 9 at the weekend by Cheryl Kernotâremember Cheryl, the one who was much more concerned about what Labor might do to Telstra in government? She was much more concerned about what Labor might do to Telstra in government because they privatised everything else that moved when they were in government. She revealed that they are going to set aside a portion of the Telstra dividend for things like education, regional development and high tech. Now this is a very cruel hoax; this is simply a pea and thimble trick because the fact is there is no new money involved. Some $996 million in dividends was paid last year and all of that money goes to a whole raft of things like education, welfare, high tech and regional development, so there is not a cracker here for people in the bush.

answer.para: What Mr Beazley is really confirming is that they are not prepared to spend any new money on people in regional and remote areas. What they are prepared to do is hoodwink them and try to pretend that somehow the money that is already being spent there is going to be looking a bit better because it has something marked alongside it calling it a special fund. I almost said it had been ringbarked. That managed to get Senator Schacht a run in the Financial Review the other day to the point where someone said Senator Schacht had been ringbarking up the wrong tree for years.

But it is much more serious than that because what Senator Schacht is proposingâand the Hansard makes this clearâis that they want the power of direction to force Telstra to upgrade the digital data capability to 64 kilobits. In other words, he wants to force Telstra to spend billions and billions of dollarsâwhich it does not have. In one fell swoop not only would you be frightening the living daylights out of the up to two million people who bought shares in the company, but you would also be removing any capacity to pay dividends. There would not be any dividends left after Senator Schacht had his go. What is tragic about this is that Labor is doing it for all the wrong reasons. They hate Telstra now, with a passion, to the point where they want to punish them for having the temerity to be supportive of privatisation.

What Senator Schacht told the estimates committee was effectively that Telstra senior management ought to resign because they were compromised by their support for privatisation. That is what this is about. He wants to cripple and kneecap Telstra by forcing them to spend billions and billions of dollars on something that is not in the slightest an economic or commercial proposition. It is not something that has been requested in rural and remote areas and it is not something that Mr Beazley is prepared to spend one red cent on and yet Senator Schacht, in one stroke, would remove any capacity to pay dividends.

The dividend last year was less than $1 billion. Senator Schacht is prepared to wipe many billions of dollars off the value of Telstra and remove any capacity to pay dividends. This is a hoax of the highest order. We are the party that has been prepared to spend real money, new moneyâ$250 million for the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund. Who opposed that tooth and nail, all the way? It has been a resounding success because it has delivered services in rural and remote areas that they would not otherwise have got.

You opposed it. What about the $1.25 billion Natural Heritage Trust? You opposed that too. That was new money that came from our policy in relation to Telstra. There will not be a cracker left to spend on the bush. There will not be much left of Telstra either, and it is all because of this vicious, nasty attack led by people like Kim Il Carr who just cannot stand the prospect of a good Australian company doing well. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI ask you to withdraw that reference to Senator Carr and refer to him by his correct name.
âI will delete his nickname and substitute his correct name.
âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. What does the government intend to do about putting infrastructure into regional and rural Australia from the Telstra dividend?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âAs Senator Boswell very much appreciates, the fact is that the RTIF has delivered unheard of benefits to rural areas and that isâ
âHe's never heard of it, Richard.

âYou don't think so? That is interesting. You do not think it has been any good so, presumably, you will not be trying to emulate it. That is fine; you will leave the territory to us. We appreciate that very much. Senator Boswell is quite right. There is a capacity for a social dividend to be paid out of the proceeds of Telstra. We are very conscious of the needs of people in rural and remote areas to get decent telephone services. They are sick and tired of being bypassed by you and treated like dirt. You are never interested in upgrading quality of service or extending roll-outs. We were the ones who gave an ISDN capability to 95 per cent of the population. They are very real benefits. Senator Boswell is right: there are a number of ways we can go further in assisting those peopleâand we will. I am delighted to hear that you could not give a damn about them.

âMy question is to Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the minister aware of comments in the West Australian newspaper last Tuesday which were critical of the government's position on native title, on guns and on the diesel fuel rebate? Does the minister agree that the Howard government:

question.para: . . . mucked around for two years before we came out with a 10-point planâ

and that this was a significant factor in the Queensland result? Does the minister also agree that Western Australian parliamentary representatives advance constituents' rights more strongly than those from other states, presumably including the party leadership in this place?

talk.start.para: âI suppose, Madam President, we will get the full story in the supplementary.
âYou will.

âThank you, Senator Cook. It will not surprise you to learn that I do not agree with those conclusions. I must say that I am proud of the national leadership the Prime Minister showed on the guns issue. It was good for Australia and the fact he has been prepared to stand his ground since I also applaud. I also believe in relation to native title that the 10-point plan is a fair and reasonable solution to a difficult national issue. It includes a considerable degree of compromise, I acknowledge, but in all the circumstances I think it is fair. It is fair to the Aboriginal people whilst at the same time it will provide greater certainty for investment and growth, and therefore jobs for all Australians. I also agree with the position the government adopted in relation to the diesel fuel rebate.

answer.para: So I am proud of what this government has done in a short period of time. It took on a $10 billion deficit that it inherited from the Labor Party and it has put that behind us. It has put the books into surplus and it has enabled interest rates to be reduced to their lowest levels for decades. That gives Australians the opportunity to invest and to prosper. I am pleased also that unemployment is coming down under this government. Its record in just over two years has placed Australia in a sound position to address the difficulties of the region and I hate to think what the consequences would have been if Labor had been elected at the last election.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given that these comments were made by your colleague Senator Winston Crane, isn't this an obvious attempt to distance himself from the failures of the Howard government, and just another example of the infighting and division within and between coalition parties as you head to an election? Given that you included Senator Winston Crane in discussions on disbursement of the Natural Heritage Trust funds, will Senator Crane now be included in cabinet discussions on native title, on guns and on the diesel fuel rebate?

question.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! There are too many people interjecting.
âI can only say that Senator Cook has obviously clearly misunderstood Senator Crane. Senator Crane would not be responsible for an evaluation of that type.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Why has this government completely defunded the national peak youth representative body, AYPAC? Is it because the government cannot work with young people or is only prepared to meet with them twice a year? Isn't it the case that the funding of $225,000 for the government's new youth policy represents a decline in funding of $140,000 for youth representation? I am wondering whether the minister can tell us how much of this money will go into research into the effect of the government's proposed common youth allowance and the permanent representation of young people in policy development, and how much of it will go into the advertising campaign and selection process described by the minister this morning on Triple J.

âLet me say at the outset that in the run-up to the last election we announced that we would have a minister in the cabinet who would be responsible for youth affairs. That is the importance we place on youth in this country. We have instituted a round table of 50 young people who will have direct input into policy making for this government. These 50 young people will come from all over Australia, not just Melbourne and Sydney but the regional areasâthe rural areas of Australia. Part of this voices of youth package will provide a direct inputâwhich was not thereâfor young people to have a say to this government. In fact, what we have done is we have established a youth website on the Internet called The Source. The Source, I am happy to say, is being visited frequently by young people and it even has a page which says, `Have your say.'

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâOh!

talk.start.para: âOrder!
âThe opposition knocks it, Madam President. That is what they think of youth; they don't want them to have a direct say.
âSenator Ellison, just a moment. Order!

âMadam President, it is obvious that the opposition does not want the youth of Australia to have access to the Internet and access to the government of this country. What we have done is set up a variety of mechanisms for the young people of this country to have a say. This round table will provide just that. It will provide a cross-section of the Australian community of youth to have a direct input to this government.

answer.para: Can I just say that there is a variety of great initiatives that this government has brought about for young people. There are the new apprenticeships which we have fundedâa target of 200,000 new apprenticeships from May this year to the end of November next year that we have contracted for. Who will be the main beneficiaries of those? Young people in Australia, from 200,000 positions that we have contracted for. What about the success of Green Corps? I think about 3,500 young Australians have participated in Green Corps.

What about work for the dole and the mutual obligation that we have brought about with an opportunity for young people who have been unemployed for more than six months to improve their literacy skillsâthose young people who need to improve their literacy skills so they can get a job? What about the work for the dole situation where we can get young people to experience working in a team, to get that work ethic, to help them get motivated to find a job? That is what we are doing for the young people of Australia, through you, Madam President, to Senator Stott-Despoja, and to the opposition that does not care about young people having access to the government via the Internet. The Internet, I might say, is a valuable tool to make contact with the young people of Australia.

This government has a proud record of providing opportunities for employment and training for young people. With this round table it is furthering that and providing a better means of direct communication with the government of this country whereby young people will be able to help formulate policy and to have their say.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister honestly believe that a chat site with Dr Kemp on the Internet is going to replace the permanent representation of young people, the input into youth policy, that AYPAC provided? Is it the case that the minister and this government have effectively silenced the voice of young Australians by providing a twice yearly meeting of a select few? Fifty peopleâthe minister said it himself. Is it any coincidence that it has been announced in the lead-up to the implementation of the government's common youth allowance? Can the minister give us an assurance as to whether or not the government will continue to fund other peak representative bodies in this nation which protect the public interest and keep the government informed, accountable and objectively assessing policies and criticising them where necessaryâinstitutions and bodies like ACROD and ACOSS? (Time expired)

âWhat this government is all about is funding the means by which young people can communicate with it. To that end we funded $3.6 million for 41 youth officers from the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs so that they could make contact with young people around the country. What is important is that young people have that line of communication with the government. If that includes having a chat with them, then I will have a chat with them any day because that is how you find out what they are thinking. That is how you find out what they want. It is not just a chat site; it is a viable means of modern communication which young people are using. Maybe it is time Senator Stott Despoja had a chat to some young people and found out what they were thinking.

âMy question is to the Minister for Social Security. I ask: can the minister confirm that since Wednesday last week Centrelink has been unable to issue payments to many of those on benefits because of computer failures? Is it true that as at Thursday last week there were over 800 unresolved problems with Centrelink's Newstart common platform? What is the minister going to do to rectify these problems? When can these many clients, who did not receive their correct payments last week, expect to receive them?

âIt is correct to say that Centrelink introduced a new information technology system early last month. It is also correct to say that it is a very significant improvement on the systems we inherited from the previous government. It is also true to say that it will be year 2000 compliant. I know that Senator West is very interested in information technology being year 2000 compliant. The previous system was not. It was very important, therefore, that a very much more effective and efficient system was introduced.

answer.para: All such systems have their teething problems. I am advised that over the last five or six weeks, out of an allowance population in excess of one million people, around 1,300 customers have received an incorrect payment or have been paid at an incorrect rate. All cases have been identified and corrective action is completed or under way according to the advice I have received. Some people may have had payment delayed for one or two days. Centrelink advises that, of the total problems reported, 364 problemsânot the 800 reported by the CPSUâfrom implementation until 18 June, almost 50 per cent, have been resolved. These are problems in the IT, not individual circumstances. The remainder are being addressed through running software updates twice weekly, running software releases overnight where necessary, and continuous assessing and revising of priorities to ensure that problems with high impact are quickly resolved.

The Newstart common platform has resulted in a better service provided to the customer due to the immediate update of the customer's records, considerable processing efficiencies in time saved, provision of a more integrated service, and the vast majority of customers being paid correctly and on time. The few problems which have arisen are being actively addressed and almost resolved. The previous system had become unreliable and inefficient. Factors which were contributing to this were processing taking place by overnight batching, whereas as the new system provides an immediate on-line response, and the previous system not being year 2000 compliant.

talk.start.para: âIs it true that the computer system for the new youth allowance crashed after 90 minutes when it was being tested last week? Can the minister outline when this chaos is expected to be completed?

âThe youth allowance is based on the Newstart common platform, so the Newstart common platform had to be introduced before the youth allowance could be implemented. The Newstart common platform has replaced the previous payment system for most benefits and allowances and it includes Newstart and the youth training allowance. Youth allowance will be paid using the Newstart common platform payment system. Most of the processing requirements for youth allowance were already included within the Newstart common platform when it was first released. The extra features of Newstart common platform that are needed to pay youth allowance represent a relatively minor component of the Newstart common platform system. Testing is currently taking place. It is not implemented until 1 July, under the usual arrangements. It was a testing system which had a problem the other day.

âMy question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Hill. I refer to recent comments by the new publicist for One Nation, Senator Lightfoot, who stated at a recent debate in Northam that `dealing with the people that Ms Hanson will put into the Senate will be far better than dealing with the Democrats and Greens', and that she, Ms Hanson, represents the type of things that Australians think and believe, which also accords with recently reported comments of the Prime Minister to the effect that One Nation would be no more damaging than the Greens or Democrats. Does this mean that, far from taking a principled stand in relation to One Nation, the Howard government's real agenda is in fact the election of One Nation senators?

âThat is a very odd thing to suggest. As for the more substantial invitation to try and compare the qualities of the newly elected One Nation members of parliament in Queensland with the known qualities of our Green and Democrat parliamentarians around the country, in all the circumstances I should avoid that.

answer.para: Those of us who see ourselves as more in the middle of Australian politics representing the mass of the Australian mainstream have a different view on issues from those who tend to represent more extreme views at either end of the spectrum.

It does, however, invite the issue that does cause concern, and that is the policies that seem to be advocated by One Nation which would result in severe economic downturns in this country, to say the very least. Policies that are anti-foreign investment fail to appreciate the great benefits that have flowed to Australians from foreign investment. Much of our capital growth has been funded offshore and, without that growth, many jobs and much of our relative affluence simply would not exist.

Policies that are simplistic and shallow and suggest that the public can in some way fund banks that would be able to lend money at two per cent, fail to appreciate the unrealistic nature of that, because of course it would have to be funded from taxpayers' money and it would simply lead to further economic downturns.

One can go through all of the policies that they are putting of that nature and realise that, in fact, the simplistic, shallow solutions simply do not work in practice. Unfortunately, there are not simple solutions to complex problems. All nation states at the moment, in time of very significant change, face complex problems and the solutions, regrettably, will be somewhat complex as well.

I am pleased to say that we are confident that we are on track. We have the expenditure now under control in this country and interest rates down to record low levels. We have given the people of Australia the chance for employment and the chance to become more prosperous. That is what I think most Australians are really looking for.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the government's difficulty in dealing with me on complex issues a result of my level of interest and involvement in a wide range of parliamentary work compared, say, with the member for Oxley, or is this a judgment on the likely agreement on anti-Aboriginal, anti-refugee, anti-environment and anti-youth legislation? Do the comments of the Prime Minister and Senator Lightfoot mean that One Nation will be assisted into the Senate on Liberal Party preferences?

âThe last thing I wish to see are One Nation senators in this place. I do not particularly want to see Green senators as well, but that has happened. Why don't I wish that? Because their would-be solutions to the real problems facing this country are simply unreal. Senator Margetts' solutions are unrealistic in the same way that One Nation's solutions are unrealistic. It is about time we started facing up to the fact, as I said, that complex problems require complex solutions and that is just part of life.

âMy question is addressed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security. Can the minister explain why the $3.8 million worth of taxpayer advertising campaign to sell the youth allowance has failed to inform families who earn more than $23,400 that after 1 July they will have to bear the burden of cuts to the benefits of their unemployed adult children? Doesn't the minister think that cutting unemployment benefits by up to $87 a week and forcing poor families to make up the difference warrants a mention in this multi-million dollar advertising campaign?

âI know that Senator Neal has been against the fair treatment of all young people in terms of the youth allowance. We have had this debate over and over again here on the legislation. But the reality is that this government's youth allowance will be treating young unemployed people in exactly the same way as young students. In other words, while they are still financially dependent and not yet standing financially on their own two feet, they must turn to their parents before they turn to the taxpayer.

answer.para: What we have introduced with the youth allowanceâand Senator Neal knows this only too wellâis a parental income test which is in fact somewhat more generous than the Austudy parental means test that we inherited. But we are treating all young people in a similar circumstance, whether they are students or unemployed, not like the previous government which had a financial incentive for young people to choose to be unemployed sometimes, rather than choose to study. That is bad for them and it is bad for the country.

As far as getting information across to parents is concerned, yes, we have spent some money to do that and we are still spending it, because we have seen what mischief a scare campaign can do in social policy areas. I have seen it already with Mr Duncan Kerr, who is trying to describe youth allowance as `poison'. We all know that that is quite untrue. It is only a scare campaign starting again.

Let parents be under no doubt about it at all. In the print advertisements there are details of the web site which allows young people and their families to surf the net and see precisely how they will be placed. The circumstances that are represented in the newspapers frequently simply give the income levels for families where there is one child. In most families, as you know, that is not the case and the income levels rise with the number of children in the family. Of course, they rise to higher levels than exist for the current Austudy that we inherited from you. There are many, many benefits.

I was in Townsville at the weekend, and I am sure Senator Reynolds will be pleased to know that the young students in Townsville think youth allowance is terrific because rent assistance at last comes with the ability to study. That is something that student organisations have been campaigning for for 20 years or more. I am glad that the young people of Townsville recognise a good, social policy reform when they see it, even if the ALP do not, because they had the opportunity to introduce it when they were in government. ACOSS and welfare organisations asked them to introduce a common youth allowance. That is what we have done.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, why has the government failed to advise battling families of the real impact of the youth allowance? Is it that you are trying to muzzle all criticism? Is it the same reason that you cut funding for the youth coalitionâbecause you want to muzzle all criticism of your latest attack on battling families?

âMadam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Neal has been very kindly assisted by this side of the chamber on several occasions suggesting that she might like to direct her question through the chair rather than personally to the minister. She has unfortunately avoided those suggestions from my colleagues. Therefore, I am wondering whether you might like to direct her attention to the standing orders.
âThere has certainly been a big improvement in the observance of the standing orders. I am sure Senator Neal will attempt to comply with them. I invite her to do so.
âWhy have the government and the minister tried to muzzle criticism of this latest attack on battling families?

âI do not try to muzzle criticism at all. I believe that information is the surest defence against misinformation. That is why a rate calculator is on the web site for youth allowance. For those who would like to look it up, it is Youthallowance.Centrelink.gov.au. You can go and see whether you can find the informa tion that you clearly need in order to realise how good it is.

answer.para: As for consulting with young people, as Senator Ellison said earlier, there is much more to consulting with young people than dealing with one peak lobby group. I meet with young people around the country. I meet with young people's organisations around the country, as do Senator Ellison and Dr Kemp. We all do. That is a way to get a strong view across all shades of political opinionârural, regional and city. The Labor Party made a huge mistake; they believed only in consulting with peak groups. Therefore, they did not know what was really happening in the country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. The minister would have seen the report from the Institute of Chartered Accountants which purports to show that a typical Australian family earning $30,000 is actually worse off than one earning $20,000 per annum. This is because of the combined effects of higher tax brackets and withdrawal of social security benefits. Will the minister outline the details of this report and tell us how this problem of high effective marginal tax rates can be addressed?

âI thank Senator Watson for his question. We know that he has always had a close and very detailed interest in taxation matters. He is a very good senator for Tasmania and is a colleague of mine. I have seen the institute's report.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senators on my left will cease sledging!

âThank you, Madam President. I wonder whether the senators opposite have also seen the report. If they need any more convincing of the need for tax reform, that report is it. It is absolutely clear. The institute's report said that a typical family on $20,000 was actually better off than a family on $30,000 after tax and social security are factored in.

answer.para: I have had my department have a good look at this report, and there was one small mistake in it. But, even on the corrected figures, the report stands as a loud condemnation of the state in which the Labor Party left our tax and social security systems. The corrected figures show that a typical single income family on $20,000 with a child in primary school and another in high school receives a total net income of $29,000. The same family, if it were earning $30,000, would only receive $30,150 in the pocket. So, for the extra $10,000 of extra work and extra pay, the family gets only $1,150 more. That is an effective marginal tax rate of 88 per cent.

Senators opposite should cringe in their seats, because they had the opportunity over 13 years to do something about it. It is your tax system that needs reforming. The Labor Party put one in place over 13 years, and it leaves battling families with marginal tax rates of 88 per cent. Let them cringe. We have already started doing something about reforming this mess, with measures like the family tax initiative, which we introduced soon after we came into government. The Institute of Chartered Accountants acknowledges this in their press release, where they have said:

There has certainly been a push by the government to redress the imbalance through both the taxation and the welfare systems. Families on $30,000 a year potentially have $27 more a week than they did last year.

So we are moving and fixing the problem, but marginal tax rates of 88 per cent are still unacceptable to this government. That is why we are committed to major and comprehensive tax reforms. It is not acceptable that in five years time average income earners will be on the top marginal tax rate of 47c in the dollar, just as today's Herald-Sun has reported. It is not acceptable that toothpaste, pet food, watches and shampoo are all taxed while antiques and caviar are not. And it is definitely not acceptable that a family working harder and earning more can lose 88 per cent of their extra pay to the government. That is the mess we inherited. That is the mess we intend to fix. What is the Labor Party's policy after this time in opposition? Still nothing. Do nothing.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, my question is directed to you. On Wednesday, 3 June, at a hearing of the Economics Legislation Committee, the chair of the committee, Senator Ferguson, ruled out of order questions I asked in relation to a memorandum I quoted. Can you advise the Senate on what basis and under what rules and Senate practices Senator Ferguson could make that ruling? Senator Ferguson then directed Hansard that extracts of the memorandum I read out, and which were later broadcast on the ABC, not be included in the Hansard .

question.para: What Senate rules and practices would enable Senator Ferguson to direct Hansard to remove these extracts? What action will you take to ensure that chairs of Senate committees act in a fair and impartial way? What action will you take to ensure that Hansard is a true and accurate record of the proceedings of Senate committees and is not censored by a committee chair, as happened on this occasion?

talk.start.para: âSenator, I have a copy of your question, and I am seeking advice as to the substance of it and the issues that occurred before that committee. I will report to the Senate on that and also on the other matters that you have raised.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, going into the last election the coalition had a lot to say about its commitment to small business. Does your commitment still apply to private child-care centre owners, who are small business people, who employ some 50,000 workers in Australia? Over the past couple of weeks the Democrats have gone out and met with private child-care centre owners throughout the country. We have heard stories of centre owners being forced to lay off staff, sell their family homes and work up to 80 hours per week just to keep their businesses afloat as occupancy rates have plummeted. My question: what will the government do to assist these private child-care centre owners who, with occupancy rates as low as 40 per cent, are now on the brink of going out of business?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Woodley for the question. It is true that certain child-care centre owners have run into troubleâbut they have run into trouble because of the policies of the previous government. As I said in a previous answer to a question from the Labor Party representatives, or from the Democrats before, I thought they should get in touch with Senator Crowley because she was the minister responsible for bring in these changes.

answer.para: The 1997 budget allocated $270 million of ongoing funds over four years to outside school hours care; this is an increase of $11 million. Earlier this year, an extra $8 million was directed to assisting services. A total of $20 million is now being directed towards services to assist with the changeover to the new arrangements. As I have said previously, the changeover is occurring because of the different type of funding. But the allocation of centres is entirely up to the sector that provides them; it is not the government's responsibility to guarantee their funding.

So, while there are some that are in trouble, there are others that are expanding. For example, I saw in one of this morning's papers a statement that there were closures of community based long day care centres and outside school hour care services, following the removal of the operational subsidy. It was stated in that newspaper report that 66 services have closed. However, it is a fact that places have increased under the Howard government. There were 48,785 places in June 1995 under Labor, and now there are 78,970 places in June 1997 under this government. So the number of places has actually increased.

The outside school hour care reforms assist low and middle income families, which is more important as well. The funding to services equivalent to the previous operational subsidy continues until the end of June: the sum of $20 million, as I mentioned, in restructuring and transitional assistance, including training for all services; a help line for advice; and individual assistance in the form of service visits. New financial support of $4.4 million per year is provided to rural, remote and isolated services to ensure continuity of supply in these regions.

Senator Woodley should take note of this: since the 1996 budget announcement to withdraw operational subsidy from community based long day care centres, 43 have closed as at 30 April 1998; however there is a net increase of 310 centres over the same period. I will repeat that for Senator Woodley: 43 centres have closed as at 30 April 1998; however, there has been a net increase of 310 centres over the same period.

The main causes of closures were ongoing financial and utilisation difficulties and a complete lack of planning measures, as I have mentioned, by the former government. This government has introduced a new planning system to direct supply to areas of greatest need. So, inevitably, with the change to a needs baseâthat centres should open in areas with the greatest needâthere will be some centres that have got into difficulty. The government has committed over $6 million over two years to June this year to assist community based long day care centres obtain financial and management advice. So I would suggest that those senators who are in trouble should access that advice to assist them.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister. I will pass on that information. Your answer raises a whole lot of further questions, but I perhaps should just concentrate on one or two. I did question Senator Crowley, and she tells me that at the election of your government none of these small businesses were in trouble; they all had waiting lists.

question.para: But let me quote to you from `A new deal for small business', your election policy:

The Liberal National Coalition recognises and appreciates the efforts of thousands of men and women who make up the small business sector. Their foresight, imagination and willingness to back their own judgment contributes 30 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product and generates employment for approximately 3.5 million people, or 45 per cent of the total work force.

Many, many of these centres are going bankrupt. What has happened since 1996 to make the government stop recognising and appreciating private child-care centre operators as small business people? (Time expired)

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI know it was the Democrats who supported the Labor Party in its policies that brought about the very high interest rates that occurredâI think up to 23 per cent under the Labor Party. I think what we have achieved in a short period of time is the lowest inflation rates for over 70 years, the lowest business interest rates for the last 10 years and the lowest home mortgage rate interest.

answer.para: There have been enormous benefits for small business that have occurred under this government in such a short period of time, especially when compared with the policies that the Democrats supported that produced a $70 billion deficit over the seven years before this government came into power. There was a $10.5 billion deficit when we came into power. But people have forgotten that over the previous seven years there was a $70 billion deficit and we were running into trouble.

The Democrats would probably do what the One Nation Party would doâprint a bit more money. But we are not into doing that. Alternatively, the Democrats would increase taxation, which seems to be their recipe. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Does the government stand by its estimate of $1 billion in savings over five years as a result of its IT outsourcing program? In the light of the incompetence the government has demonstrated in the implementation of this program, with only one contract having been let and another withdrawn, how does the government expect to achieve these savings? And, if the government has revised its savings forecast, what is the current estimate?

âI will seek some advice from the Minister for Finance on it, but there is no doubt that very significant savings would flow from sensible outsourcingâI think that that is obvious to anyoneâand sensible outsourcing will occur under this government. If it is being suggested to me that it is a complex process and that it would take some time, I am not surprised to hear that, but I also, equally, have no doubt that the benefits will flow that will reduce the cost to public expenditureâsomething the Labor Party was not prepared to face up to in government. This government, as an alternative, believes that prudent control of public expenditure is important so that all benefits can therefore flow to the Australian people through lower interest rates, low inflation and other ways in which the people rather than the government can obtain the benefit. I will seek further information on the detail and see if I can help you further, Senator.

âSenator Hill, I hope you have more luck extracting the information from the Minister for Finance than anyone else. Madam President, my supplementary question is: what was the cost of the failed tender process for the DEETYA-Employment National IT outsourcing contract, and what savings has the government forgone by withdrawing that tender?
âI could take a guess, but I think that would be unwise. I will seek the answer to that, and let you know.

âMy question is to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. The minister will, no doubt, be aware of last Wednesday's stop-work meeting by the New South Wales Teachers Federation which brought government schools to a standstill. Will the minister outline why, besides interrupting classes of thousands of students across New South Wales, the union's action was ill-conceived and irresponsible? Will the minister outline, for the parents and people of Australia, this government's commitment to education in Australia?

âSenator Coonan is right: thousands of students in New South Walesâin fact, just under 800,000 studentsâwere inconvenienced by this ill-conceived strike by New South Wales teachers. In fact, it was an effort by the teachers' union to start up their campaign against the Howard government. They wanted to mislead the New South Wales community, teachers and parents as to the true position of federal funding for government schools. Of course, they did not tell the people of New South Wales that the federal government has increased funding for government schools by 7.4 per cent. In fact, for the period 1997-2000, this government would have increased funding for government schools across the country by $1.9 billion.

answer.para: This government believes in a strong government school sector and a strong non-government school sector. We believe in choice. We went to the people of Australia at the last election and said that was our policy, and they elected us on that basis. It is interesting to see what the Sydney Morning Herald editorial of Thursday last week, headed `School stunt', had to say about the New South Wales teachers strike. It said:
It is hard to imagine a more transparent political stunt than yesterday's stopwork meeting by teachers in New South Wales Government schools.
Clearly the Teachers Federation was firing its first shot at the Howard Government in the Federal election campaign . . .
There you have itâit was nothing more, nothing less, than a go at the federal government. Even the Sydney Morning Herald realised what a transparent and misleading action this was.

Let us have a look at the objectives of the teachers' union. They have got 16 objectives on the Internet; only one of them deals with educationâonly one out of 16. Do you know where it ranks? Number 10 out of 16. I ask you: if they are so interested in the welfare of the students and teachers of New South Wales, why don't they at least put education up the list a bit; maybe one or two, but not number 10.
The Sydney Morning Herald editorial goes on to say:
But the things upsetting themâ
meaning the teachers' unionâ
have more to do with State Government policies than Federal policies.

In fact, what they are really complaining about is what the Carr government is not doing. They should really be concentrating on the Carr governmentâlet us see them attack the Carr Labor government in New South Wales. But, of course, they are attacking the federal government because that is really what they are after. They will not tell the people of New South Wales that we have increased funding. In fact, when you look at the 1998 figures, our funding per capita of government schools was $2,144âan increase of $157 per capita over Labor's last year in power. So there you have it: we have increased funding on a per capita basis since Labor was in power. And what did the teachers union do in New South Wales? It went on strike; it deserted just under 800,000 students.

What are we doing? We have got increased funding of $45 million over four years for literacy and numeracy initiatives; with the cooperation of states and territories we have brought about national literacy benchmarks for the first time in Australia; we are spending $187 million over the period 1997 to 2000 on vocational educationâ
Senator Sherry interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âVocational education, Senator Sherry, which you should be more interested in; vocational education which touches those 70 per cent of students who do not go on to university. It addresses their needs, helps them get a job and puts them on the career pathways that they need. We have also got increased funding in the areas of indigenous education, discovering civics and a whole range of other initiatives. (Time expired)
âMadam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
âOn 23 April 1998 the Director of Public Prosecutions was asked for advice on whether incorrect travelling allowance claims by senators found by the KPMG internal audit should be investigated.

speech.para: On 29 May 1998 the Senior Assistant Director of Public Prosecutions, having examined relevant travelling allowance claims and correspondence, concluded that `the material provided does not disclose matters that should be the subject of criminal investigation'.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given today by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), to questions without notice asked by Senators Neal and West today, relating to Centrelink and the youth allowance.

This largely relates to the recent changes occurring in the youth allowance area. I suppose what always astonishes me so much about this particular government, and to some extent Senator Newman's views of those policies as they relate to youth allowance, is that they constantly state that they support families and they support battling families but this is not in accordance with what they are actually doing. On every occasion when they have an opportunity, this government and this Minister for Social Security in fact reduce the amount of money that is in families' pockets, and they often take the money out of the pockets of the families who are worst off.

It was interesting that the minister noted that the issue of battling families was one that was raised on a number of occasions in debate in this chamber on the youth allowance, where we discovered, much to our concern, that almost 48,000 families who are not very well-offâfamilies earning just over $23,000âwould be worse off as a result of the youth allowance bill introduced by this minister. It is interesting to me that, despite the questions that have been raised today and despite numerous matters that have been raised in this chamber before, this government seems to be unable to see that a family on $23,400 is not a family that is well-off.

I found it quite extraordinary that Senator Newman, during the debate on the youth allowance bill, told this chamber and the people of Australia that such families that had at least one adult child over the age of 18 years were well-off. Let me tell Senator Hill, Senator Newman and all the other senators on the other side that most people in Australia do not think that a family that earns $23,000 is well-off. In fact, most people would think that families that were earning that sort of money were really struggling. It is quite extraordinary that this government, which said during the election that they intended to look after battling families, families that were really having a hard time of it, are making it even more difficult for those families by taking away $87 per week when there is an adult child who is unemployed. That is what this youth allowance legislation does.

It seems that the rush to get this legislation through and the rush to get the information technology up might all be for nothing, because it appears, from Senator West's question and the response that was received, that there are so many problems in the computer system and in the new newstart computer platform that it seems unlikely to me that within such a short time before 1 July they will really have it operating properly. The question that was put to Senator Newman was whether the youth allowance computer system had crashed after just 90 minutes of running. I thought it was quite extraordinary that Senator Newman was unwilling or unable to answer that question. She managed to avoid it and to talk about the difficulties of the year 2000 in relation to computer programs. I am sure it is very interesting for people to discuss the issues of the millennium bug, but that was not the question that was directed to her by Senator West. What we are trying to discover is whether this government, which says it is going to introduce this new youth allowance package on 1 July, is really in a position to do so and whether the computer system that has been set up, at major cost to the government and to taxpayers, is in fact in a position to operate effectively as of 1 July.

Despite all these difficulties and the fact that the government are spending $3.8 million on telling the Australian community what a brilliant policy response they have made, they have failed to tell those families who are struggling, those earning $23,400, that many of themâalmost 50,000 of themâare in fact going to be worse off as a result of the youth allowance package. It seems quite extraordinary that you can expend that much money over a very short period; we were told at estimates that that $3.8 million would be spent in just one month. I think the vast majority of Australians would believe that spending that sort of money while taking $87 out of poor families' pockets is very much a waste. It appears to me that the government are spending $3.8 million on promoting themselves in order to put themselves in a better position for the election. They are spending $3.8 million of taxpayers' money to try and convince those battling families whose pockets they are grabbing money out of that, even though they are losing money, the Howard government is in fact helping them by doing so. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe extraordinary thing about Labor's sustained attack on the youth allowance is that it is an attack on an initiative which is actually designed to assist young people. What never fails to amaze me is why it would be suggested that we as the party in government would set out to deliberately make things more difficult for young people. It is pretty obvious that the youth allowance is actually assisting young people or else we would not have this sustained, ongoing and unjustifiable attack.

speech.para: The salient and the very good features of the youth allowance, which it is necessary to repeat once again, include the most attractive feature of it, which is that it simplifies income support arrangements for young people by combining five payments types and by reducing 13 different rates to just five. The complicated previous system that Labor had pursued left so many people falling between stools and not getting any assistance at all that it was necessary to actually look at how this youth allowance could be streamlined. It will now align both rates and qualifications for all young people up to the age of 21 and remove that incentive for young people to leave education early or to choose unemployment over education or training. It is blindingly obvious that those young people who get education and training will have better opportunities to get jobs.

Parental means testing of students and unemployed people aged up to 21 will also be aligned. You have heard the minister say today that young people with the lowest income families will continue to qualify for maximum rates of assistance under the parental means test. There is nothing unfair about that. Access to rent assistance for students and for unemployed 16- to 17-year-olds who live away from home for education or employment reasons is also a significant advance under this policy. Rent assistance is also available to independent young people who live away from home. What a relief it must be for young people who are not living at home and who need rent assistance to actually have that assistance available to them. A flexible activity test allows young people to undertake a variety of activities without having to change payment type.

The abolition of the education leavers deferment period will ensure continuity of income support between leaving school and commencing full-time employment. Students will have access to a higher fortnightly income free income and an income bank of $6,000 designed to accommodate student work patterns for full-time casual employment over vacation periods. That is a significant advance compared to the old policy, under which casual employment actually disqualified people from their benefits; they went on, they went off and they did not know where they were with 13 different rates. The changed independence criteria are, of course, more lenient for students and tighter for some unemployed young people. All youth allowees will have access to the $500 loan advance currently made available under Newstart. That is a great benefit for young people.

There are many winners from the youth allowance. Of the 560,000 young people who will be covered by youth allowance, 416,000 are students and 144,000 are unemployed. Payment for 358,600 will remain unchanged and payment for 153,750 young people will increase. All young people will benefit from the simplified income support system, which provides incentives to remain in education and training and which has the flexibility to cater for a variety of activities undertaken by young people in their transition from school to employment. Students not only gain from the availability of rent assistance but all under 18-year-olds who have to live away from home gain from the increased rates. This is a significant advance and a superior initiative to assist young people into employment.

talk.start.para: âSenator Coonan has just told us about the wonderful things that her government is doing for people who have dealings with Centrelink. Senator Neal covered quite a lot of her question in that regard in question time. I would like to take this a little bit further with regard to Centrelink. I have had quite a lot of complaints to my office in Ipswich regarding this area. I would like the Senate to know of a couple in particular. The first is from a young man who lives in Caboolture and I would urge the minister to look at the Centrelink in Caboolture to see what can be done.

speech.para: This man had been to Centrelink at Caboolture and had seen a job on the screen that he felt he was well qualified for. First of all, he rang the number and was told to go all the way to Chermside for an interview. When he said that he lived in Caboolture and the job was also in Caboolture, he was referred to the BAVE Caboolture office. He took his qualifications and one written reference. All of his past employers had advised him that they were willing to provide verbal references whenever they were called for. He took all of his documents, about 10 pages in all, which would have gained him jobs through the CES in the pastâhe had used these in the past with the CESâand went along to this BAV office in Caboolture. When he presented his resume, apparently the staff member there looked down his nose at him and advised him that his resume was not good enough and that was that. I cannot believe that public servants supposedly there to help people find employment are looking down their noses and saying, `Your resume is not good enough.'

I have here another letter from a pensioner. This man also lives in Caboolture. He phoned the 132300 phone number and told them that his 1998 pensioner concession card and his 1998 Queensland travel vouchers were lost. He had not received them. He says:

In mid January I phoned the Centrelink customer service office in Caloundra and told them my pensioner card had not been received. I was told they would look into the matter and send the card with the concessions to me in two weeks.

Two weeks later I received the concession card but the Queensland travel vouchers were also stamped void. When I enquired about the vouchers they said I must have lost my card and received a second issue.
He explained that this was his first pensioner card and travel vouchers. He continued:

Centrelink then told me to fill out a Statutory Declaration then send it with my documents to Queensland Rail as they cannot send any replacements. 29 April I phoned Centrelink 132300 number to make an appointment to see one of their officers for help in filling out the Statutory Declaration and what it was for. Centrelink said that would not be necessary they would send me out a letter that day. Thinking I was talking to some person at the Caloundra office, the letter should be in the mail the next day. 6th May the letter arrived one week later, with Caloundra Post Box number and Caloundra Centrelink address. The letter stating I may not have received by W.A. free rail passes and to send all my documents on to West-Rail to receive new rail passes. The letter was posted from Bunbury W.A.

To cut it short, he phoned Bunbury, Western Australia and said, `Well, I am sorry, that is very nice of you, but I do live in Queensland. I need Queensland Rail passes.' This poor man then rang Centrelink again and he said, `I live in Caboolture. Am I speaking to Caboolture or Brisbane or somewhere in Queensland?' `No,' they said. `This is the Adelaide office, but we will put you through to the Brisbane office.'
This is not funny. I am laughing, but I am laughing because it is the most disgraceful thing I have ever seen. This poor man finally got it all sorted out. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe opposition, in taking note of Senator Newman's answer to a question on the youth allowance, criticised the government in a number of areas. The first that I would address is their criticism of the government educating members of the community and explaining the new system. Senator Neal has addressed this issue, in particular criticising the government for placing some money into the budget expenditure on this very issue.

speech.para: It seems to me and to many others that it is the opposition who would be the first to criticise and the first to complain if a new system were introduced without an effort being made to explain its new aspects to the users of that system. It seems to me that they would be the first to complain if it were not appropriately tested. Senator Neal took issue with that today.

Senator Coonan addressed some of the changes which will be introduced. The most important of the changes is a simplification of income support arrangements for young Australians that combines five payment types and reduces 13 different rates to just fiveâthat is, it simplifies the entire system for the users and the operators and enables young Australians to access the system more effectively.

As I think Senator Coonan noted, this is an initiative designed to assist young peopleâand let us begin there. For years and years there were complaints about the inequities in the system and the lack of incentive for young people to take up further education and training. I well remember, even in 1987, the much vaunted Priority One program of the previous governmentâa program that was said to be the answer to the problems of all young Australians. It was certainly decided some years later that it was not any sort of an answerâmore like Priority None than Priority One.

In addressing the question of youth allowance, the government has introduced positive initiatives to assist young Australians. The Labor Party, over the 13 years it was in government in this country, had every chance to increase the standard of living of Australian students, and it simply did not do so. This is a social policy reform which is intended to make sure that young people do not see unemployment benefits as the only acceptable alternative to study. It is intended to make sure that those aged under 18 do not just go on the dole but that there is some opportunity for skills acquisition and further training. It is all about incentive. No matter which way you look at it, for years and years the inequity between payments for Austudy and for unemployment benefits simply resulted in young people making the easier decision and choosing unemployment benefits rather than pursuing further education and training. It is this issue which the government has addressed with the changes to the youth allowance system.

Let us look at issues like rent assistance. Young students from country areas in particular were not able to pursue an education because their low to even middle income parents could not afford to send them away. As the minister said in her second reading speech, there is now an opportunity for families, especially those with several children, to be able to afford to send their young people away for further education largely because of the availability of rent assistance which makes a real difference. They have a chance of getting skills; they have a chance of getting an education.

This is merely one aspect of the government's initiatives in this area. I have spent months and months in various regional parts of New South Wales looking at government initiatives in relation to young people, particularly work for the dole, where young people have finally found some incentive and some initiative to participate in schemes and programs such as this. These are not programs that just shift numbers around as they were under the previous governmentâstatistically convenient, yes, but in reality doing nothing for the young Australians they were supposed to benefit.

What we are doing in the initiatives under the youth allowance changes is making it clear that those young people, particularly under the age of 18, should focusâand so should their familiesâon what is valuable from training and education. Academic education, yes; vocational training, as the minister has previously said, yes. It is all about leading to jobs and to greater opportunities for people to participate in the work force. It is all about assisting young people and providing a focus for their activities when there are difficulties in other areas. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI also want to address the issue of Centrelink. To start with, I want to quote from an article in the Tasmanian Mercury last Wednesday, the 17th, headed `Rush to recover payouts in dole bungle'. It reads:

speech.para: Social Security officials are scrambling to recover unemployment benefits which may have been paid accidentally to hundreds of Tasmanians.
A glitch in Centrelink's new computer system caused former social security recipients to be put back on the payment list.
The programming bug has also resulted in some unemployed Tasmanians missing out on benefits and others receiving double payments.

I want to address briefly the issue of some people missing out on their unemployment benefits. I have had a lass in my Ulverstone office over the last few weeksâactually a longer period than thatâwho has had her last four cheques not go into her account on time. The last cheque was paid in the following day. My officers work on this each time her payments have not come in. They have phoned Centrelink and we have been assured that the problem has been fixed. We will be interested to see the next time the payment is due whether it goes in on time, but it certainly has not been going on in time.

This lass is a young woman living in Ulverstone. She has no family support. She has done some casual work here and there, but she relies on that payment. She has absolutely no other means of support at this stage. It is frightening for her to go to her bank and find nothing has been paid in.

Another case has come to my office of a woman who was caring for her pensioner husband. She lived out in the country, outside Devonport. Her husband was taken ill and hospitalised. She moved into town at the time of his hospitalisation and he passed on. She is a woman of 60 or 61. She stayed in town to make his funeral arrangements and those sorts of things. She went to Centrelink to tell them of the change in her circumstances. She was told to fill in documents, which she did. She was told to wait in a queue. She waited two hours under very stressful circumstances, because her husband had just died. Six weeks later she has had no acknowledgment of her application for assistance. She is still waiting to hear what Centrelink are going to do to try to resolve her situation.

Those sorts of cases are very difficult. They should not be happening. They are happening to peopleâand particularly in this woman's caseâwho are stressed and are not thinking clearly. She needs assistance, but it is not forthcoming. She has had a very difficult time.

The article in the Mercury also states, `As far as customers are concerned, the problem is totally ironed out.' As I have explained, in two of the cases that have come to meâthere have been others, but these are two very diverse casesâthe problem has not been ironed out. Certainly in the area where I live it has not been ironed out. Hopefully, it will be addressed and addressed soon.

The CPSU put out a media release in March warning that this new computer system would fail and that staffing levels should be maintained. I think they have proven their point. This new computer system has failed. They go on to say that the warning was ignored, experienced IT staff left, 1,300 jobs were cut and now there is a major problem. Information I have today, which is contrary to what Senator Newman has said, tells me that, as from lunch time today, there are still 827 faults in the system. Somewhere someone needs to check these facts because that was what came to me todayâ827 faults still in the system.

talk.start.para: âWe just heard Senator Denman and the previous Labor speaker, Senator Gibbs, take their five minutes to relate a very personal story directly related to their electorates. Not doubting that those stories have substance, though they may have embellished them somewhat as they came into the parliament, the truth of the matter isâand every parliamentarian know this; members of the House of Representatives and senators from both sides of the houseâwhen there is a genuine social security problem, a constituent comes to your office, inevitably that can be fixed up by the office of the ministerâfrom either side of the parliament and in the previous government. When there are personal problems, the staff of the ministers will attend to those directly. So to come in here and use that as an example of the utter failure of the new system this government is trying to introduce is wrong and adds no substance to the argument at all.

speech.para: When the coalition first came into government it was met with a social welfare system that was riddled with fraud, that was complex, that was totally overloaded and that was simply out of date. Quite frankly, in many parts of the community it was quite resented. That is what was allowed to be built up over the last 13 years of the previous government.

talk.start.para: âJeff Kennett was right.
âThat was the system we came into.
âHe was right, wasn't he?
âOrder! Senator Carr!

âMadam Deputy President, allow me not to be baited by Senator Carr with that tiresome interjection that he uses against me on each and every occasion. On our coming into government we were met with that sort of system and no other minister in the last 13 years or since Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was the Minister for Social Security has brought such reform to the system. She has brought a discipline to the department not previously seen and a responsibility to the department not previously seen.

speech.para: Quite frankly, as Senator Payne pointed out in her address, there have been years of concern and complaint and the minister has acted quite responsibly and aggressively to clean up those complaints within the system. First of all, she has clamped down on social security fraud. That is exactly what the community asked for. The community had a pent-up resentment against the system. We have clamped down on fraud and we are saving some $28 million a weekâa phenomenal amount. But our reforms do not take benefits away from people who qualify for them; we have just clamped down on fraud.

It is important to note that the youth allowance is an important reform. People should have the facts before them. First and foremost, all the research shows that young people have a much better chance of getting a job if they have at least completed year 12. I am saying this for the benefit of those gigglers up in there in the gallery. Youth allowance provides the right incentives by making sure young people are not better off on the dole but are able to complete their education or training. This measure targets students, that is, around 70 per cent of the total youth allowance population of around 560,000.

Access to the youth allowance will mean that, for the first time, young people will have access to the same benefits available to young unemployed people: rent assistance, pharmaceutical assistance, a $500 interest free advance on their payment and more lenient, independent criteria.
Senator Margetts interjectingâ
Senator Stott Despoja interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYou doubt that there will be more lenient, independent criteria?
âOrder! Senator Margetts and Senator Stott Despoja! Senator McGauran, would you please address the chair and ignore the interjections coming from down there?
âOrder! Senator Faulkner! Senator McGauran, please continue.

âThank you, Madam Deputy President. If students have to leave home to study or to trainânamely, students from rural and regional areas of Australiaâthe youth allowance gives them extra help. (Time expired)
âOrder! The time for the debate has expired.
âIt is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 5 June 1998 of former Senator Donald Newton Cameron, a senator for the state of South Australia from 1969 to 1978.
âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Friday, 5 June 1998, of Donald Newton Cameron, a senator for the State of South Australia from 1969 to 1978, places on record its appreciation of his public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Don Cameron was born at Murray Bridge, South Australia on 13 January 1914. He was educated at Gawler High School and, after leaving school, worked as a shearer. Before entering federal politics, Don was an organiser with the Australian Workers Union. He was Secretary of the South Australian Branch of the AWU from 1965 to 1969. He was also President of the South Australian Branch of the Australian Labor Party from 1967 to 1968.

Don was elected to the Senate in 1969 to fill a casual vacancy and remained in the Senate until his retirement in 1978.
