During his time in the Senate Don was a member of various committees, including the Senate Legislative and General Purpose Committee on Health and Welfare and the Senate Legislative and General Purpose Committee on Trade and Commerce.

In June 1978, valedictory speeches were made in the Senate noting the retirement of several senators. In these remarks, Don was characterised as being a quiet senator who was an ardent worker, often adding wisdom in contributions to debate. This was considered to distinguish his speeches from the ordinary party arguments in the parliament at the time. Don Cameron was, indeed, a tireless worker during his time in the Senate and will be remembered kindly and with the same respect which he earned while serving in this place.
Madam President, on behalf of the government, l extend to his wife, Colleen, and his family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

talk.start.para: âI rise on behalf of the opposition to support this condolence motion that has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate on the death of Don Cameron, who was, of course, a very well known former South Australian Labor senator. I say on behalf of the opposition that Labor senators do express our deep regret over his death and we offer our most sincere condolences to his wife, Colleen, and his family.

speech.para: As Senator Hill has indicated, Don Cameron was first elected to the Senate in 1969 to fill a casual vacancy. He retired in 1978 after serving the people of the state of South Australia with great dedication and distinction for those nine years in the parliament. He was a man of honour and character, and I know he really will be missed very much by his colleagues, particularly his friends in South Australia.

While I did not know Don Cameron personally, I certainly know members of his family. His brother, Clyde Cameron, is of course well known to many of us on this side of the chamber and is very well known in Australian politics. His son, Terry Cameron, is someone with whom I have had an association in the Labor Party. He is currently a member of the Legislative Council in the state of South Australia. He has been very active in the Labor Party at an organisational level, including serving in a senior role as vice-president of the party nationally and as a member of our party's national executive.

I do think it is proper to say that, as we remember the contribution that Don Cameron has made, it will be in that area of his commitment to the trade union movement over a very long period of time. He was the secretary of the South Australian branch of the Australian Workers Union and had a lifelong commitment to that trade union. Also, he had been a very important figure in the Labor Party organisationally in South Australia, including serving as the South Australian President of our party. I noted that on his retirement from the Senate one of his friends and colleagues, former Senator Reg Bishop, another Labor Senator from South Australia, said about him:

Senator Don Cameron has been a person who has often added wisdom in contributions to debates which has distinguished his speeches from the ordinary party arguments in the parliament. He has been able to contribute some gem of wisdom to debates on many causes which have had to be propounded. He has been a most distinguished member of the parliament.

I am sure that is a very accurate reflection of the contribution that Don Cameron made. We, in the Labor Party particularly, will remember the contribution and commitment that Don Cameron has made to the labour movement. That is what we will never forget. We will of course remember his dedication to our party as well as his distinguished parliamentary career. On behalf of the opposition, can I say to his familyâhis wife of over 50 years, Colleen, who survives him; his sons, Terry and Barry; Clyde and other members of his familyâand all his friends in South Australia: we offer our most sincere condolences.

talk.start.para: âI want to make a few remarks in respect of the condolence motion that has been moved in the Senate this afternoon. I think many people know that Don Cameron and the Cameron family have been very close friends of mine. I had a lot to do with Don Cameron in particular over a number of years. It is with sadness today that I note his passing, not because he has not had a long lifeâ84 years is a very long, and in Don's case, a very productive life in a whole range of different waysâbut because I guess the moment has come now when we here in this chamber remember someone who once served in here and indeed went on for another 20 years of life and service to the community and the Labor Party. Particularly in the last 10 years or so, I think the advice he gave to many new members both in state and federal politics was very useful.

speech.para: Don Cameron did not have the flamboyance of Clyde. Clyde, whom we all know, has featured both in television programs of the era and in many publications. But make no bones about the fact that Clyde would be the first person to say that much of what he did was possible only because his brother played a significant and key role in the trade union movement in South Australia.

Indeed, Don was a very selfless man. Don did not seek high office. Don did not seek anything for himself. What Don sought was the betterment of his members, firstly, and, secondly, to look after the underdog, whoever that may be. He did that in his union service, he did that in his parliamentary service, he did that in every part of his life.

Don was instrumental not only in Clyde's career but in the careers of a few others as well. I well remember the late Mick Young telling me a story that he turned up in Broken Hill when Don Cameron was a shearer at that timeâand he spent quite a lot of his life as a shearer. Mick, at the age of 18, had just shown the older hands how to shear a sheep and Don Cameron immediately recognised Mick's greatnessâbut not for shearing a sheep. He said, `Mick, I think you ought to be going into the union office. It is probably not a good idea for you to stay a shearer here much longer.' The tally was getting too low. In many respects Don started Mick's career in the union movement and eventually in politics.

Don was elected as the Secretary of the AWU in 1964. It was an election that was fraught with controversy. In fact, there was eastern states intervention in the union. Don found himself literally out of work in November 1964, with two young kids to feed. Indeed, it was a long legal battle before the democratic right and the democratic tradition of the AWU was upheld in the courts some nine months later. I draw this to the attention of the Senate here today because Don Cameron, at that time, had to literally go out and get whatever work he could get. He was out on a broom for something like nine months to feed his wife and kids while the court case was going onâand Don never wavered. Don was there and his friends, Mick Young and Jack Wrightâwho were other officials in this unionâand many of the other people who had been very important in the Labor Party in the 1970s and the 1980s, were at Don's side.

The advocate for Don's cause, Dame Roma Mitchell, who also went on to other things, took a very close interest. Eventually the case was won and Don was reinstated as the divisional secretary in South Australia. Dame Roma never lost interest in these fellows. When Keith Plunkett died some two years or so ago nowâhe was another one of Don's contemporariesâDame Roma went to the funeral and said she wanted to mark the passing of one of her boys.

When Don Cameron came into this place I think he was one of the last senators to face a state wide by-election, which is the way replacements were found. He served here until 1978. He never sought for himself high office because he did not have the ego that demanded that particular thing. Don wanted to serve his constituents as best he could. Don did serve his constituents the best way he knew how.

Don was an intensely private man who had party contacts right up until the very end. Sadly, in the last two years his health declined to such a point that he could not go outside his own house. Every couple of weeks he would roll up on a Friday to a restaurant in Adelaide's Chinatown that many in Labor politics in South Australia go to, but for the last two years he has been unable to do that. There were many times when we hoped that his health would improve, but unfortunately it went down further and further and it became impossible for him to have any quality of life. I hosted a dinner for him in that same restaurant on the occasion of his 80th birthday four years agoâit seems that time has flown.

There are many people in South Australiaâmany members of the Labor Partyâwho have a great deal of respect for Don and would like those remarks put on the public record here today. Indeed, Don Cameron was a person who quite openly would give advice to people. In fact I noticed, in looking through his parliamentary records, that when he was retiring a number of senators made note of the fact that Don Cameron was more of a friend to them than anything else. One of those, of course, was ex-Senator Neville Bonner, who made the comment about Don Cameron that had it not been for him he would have found the transition into the Senate very difficult indeed. Don went out of his way, in the words of ex-Senator Bonner, to make sure that he felt at home here and showed him the ropes in the first critical few months of his service to the Senate.

Don Cameron is survived by his wife of over 50 years, Colleen, his son Terry Cameron, who is a Legislative Councillor, and his other son Barry. They and Clyde and Doris and other close members of the family all said goodbye to Don at a private ceremony the other week. Don left instructions that he was to be privately cremated with only close family at that particular service because it was not in Don's nature that he would want it otherwise.

I am sad at the loss of a friend and confidant. I would be remiss in not saying here that the last time this man took part in any Labor Party activity was to come to the preselection conventionâhe was very ill at the timeâon 8 May last year and cast his vote for me.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the condolence motion for the passing of Don Cameron. I suspect I may be one of the few senators who were aware of Don when he was secretary of the AWU in South Australia in the mid to late 1960s when I was first active in the Labor Party and certainly when I became an organiser in the party in 1969.

speech.para: As Senator Quirke has mentioned, Don Cameron was elected to a casual vacancy in the Senate created by the passing of a senator. In those days, at the first opportunity for a statewide electionâif the House of Representatives election was out of sync with the Senate electionâan election would take place. At the 1969 federal election, which was a House of Representatives election with no Senate election, the vacancy could be voted on and Don Cameron had already been selected as the Labor Party half-Senate candidate. As a non-sitting candidate, he was our candidate for that by-election, if you could call it that, and he beat another CameronâMartin Cameronâin that ballot. Martin Cameron is the present president of the Liberal Party in South Australia who, after being defeated by Don because he had been appointed to the vacancy, went on to become a Legislative Councillor, a founding member of the Liberal movement in South Australia, and is now president of the South Australian Liberal Party. Don beat him in that 1969 election.

I remember it well. It was the first election I was involved in as a party official when the Labor Party two-party preferred vote in South Australia at a federal election reached something like 54 per cent and we won five seats from the Liberal Party. Don came into the Senate at that time and, to my surprise I must sayâand many of us tried to talk him out of itâhe decided to retire in 1978 after barely nine years in the Senate. Many of us were quite surprised that he chose to retire after what was a relatively short period in the Senate. He certainly had the support of the party to continue for a longer period, if he had so chosen. But that, as Senator Quirke has said, was typical of Don Cameron; he did not seek the limelight for himself, though all of us who knew him realised he was a figure of considerable substance and calibre within the Labor movement in South Australia, both as a trade unionist and as a member of the Labor Party.

Don Cameron provided quiet advice to many of us who were much younger than him in those days. That advice would always be about the morality, the ethics and the consistency of what one should believe in. That was certainly Don's role and he had an influence much greater than most would believe. It is true that in a most celebrated case in AWU history Don won election as secretary, then was sacked by the then federal secretary of the Labor Party, Tom Dougherty. That was taken to the court. Roma Mitchell was the defender, as Senator Quirke said, of Don Cameron and the others who were sacked at that time. The court upheld the case that they should be reinstated.

In the group that Senator Quirk has mentioned there was Reg Groth, who went on to become state member for Salisbury for a decade in the Dunstan years; Jimmy Dunford, who went on to become secretary of the AWU and ultimately a member of the Legislative Council in South Australia and who, sadly, died in office in the early 1980s; Alan Beggs, who went on to become secretary of the AWU in South Australia; Jack Wright, who was Don Cameron's successor as state secretary of the AWU and who then became a member of the parliament in South Australia; and, ultimately, Deputy Prime Minister in the Bannon Labor government. There were a number of others, such as Keith Plunkett. I do not think Keith was actually sacked by Tom Dougherty in those days because I do not think he had been appointed or elected as an official, but he certainly was an activist. I may have missed some other names in that celebrated groupâ

talk.start.para: âMick Young.

âMick Young wasn't actually sacked. Mick had already just been elected before the sacking to be the state organiser of the Labor Party in South Australia. Though socially and politically he was very close to them, he had already just moved on from being the AWU organiser at Port Pirie to be the ALP organiser, and we know of Mick's celebrated career in the Labor Party since that time.

speech.para: One cannot underestimate the success that Don Cameron and that team of people had in the AWU in South Australia in creating a climate for the Dunstan decade of the 1970s. Don Cameron was a very strong supporter of Don Dunstan and the many radical reforms that Don Dunstan introduced and put into place in the Labor Party in the famous Dunstan decade. Though Don Cameron had in every way a classic working class background, he certainly supported Don on many of the wider social and reform issues that he introduced in South Australia. That was a very important base for the success of the Labor Party in that period. Though Don Cameron is not given much credit, he should be given a lot of credit for it. As one who was an official in the Labor Party in the Dunstan decade, I know the role that Don played in the late 1960s and then in the early 1970s as one of those influential figures.

When I worked for the Whitlam government for a period of time with Senator Bishop, who was a close colleague of Don Cameron's, I had plenty of opportunity to see the work that Don did in the Senate during that period. Don's advice, balance and comment were always sound at a time when, to the say the least, the Whitlam government was providing some pretty exciting times and opportunities. Again, Don Cameron always supported those who were in favour of reform, whether it was economic or social. Though he might not get the credit that he should have got for the Dunstan decade, he was an important figure behind the scenes in the Whitlam period.

As I said earlier in my remarks, many of us were very surprised that Don chose to retire from the Senate in 1978. I agree with Senator Quirk that Don Cameron continued to have an intense interest in the Labor Party and the labour movement. If one had to say about Don what would he like to be remembered for, there is no doubt that he would like to be remembered as an outstanding trade union official and secretary of the AWU, representing the workers and their interests, particularly low paid and semi-skilled workers, which overwhelmingly AWU members were in those days and still are.

I remember being a very green 22-year-old state organiser for the Labor Party in the 1969 federal campaign and then in the 1970s state campaign that began the Dunstan decade and being taken by Don to the Riverland of South Australia to speak at factory gate meetings, if you could call them that, that in fact were under an orange tree outside a packing shed or a cannery, and to talk to workers about those issues that we were promoting at the election. The way Don handled himself in talkingâusing simple but effective languageâto ordinary people about the issues of the day was a real lesson to me about how to communicate. I have to say, he did it better than most. His record in the Labor Party in South Australia, in the Trades and Labour Council in South Australia and in the trade union movement is very significant.

It was with considerable sorrow that I heard of his passing. I pass on to his wife and family, Terry and Barry, my sincere condolences and also the fact that in my very young days in the Labor Party Don Cameron had an influence on my involvement in the labour movement beyond most others. For that I am eternally grateful.

talk.start.para: âI too wish to pay tribute to Don Cameron in speaking to this condolence motion. I did not know Don Cameron very much as a senator, I have to say. I did know him as a union official. He was one of the first union officials I encountered when I started work as an industrial officer for the Clerks Union in South Australia in 1967. He was then President of the Australian Labor Party and continued as President of the ALP for at least another year.

speech.para: Don Cameron was an outstanding figure, as we have heard from my colleagues Senator Quirk, Senator Schacht and Senator Faulkner, in the South Australian union movement. He was, as the record shows, a long time secretary of the AWU. What the record does not show is that he held that position with considerable distinction and great admiration and respect were accorded to him by the rank and file members of that organisation. He was in many respects a union official of the old school, who held the rank and file point of view on all points in an argument and who saw it as his role to represent that point of view as fully, as frankly and as openly as he could. He did that to considerable effect.

I know that he was associated with the people in South Australia who were the luminaries of the AWU at the timeâpeople such as Mick Young. A number of the names have been mentioned here today. There was Jack Wright, Jimmy Dunford and Alan Beggs. I remember particularly the industrial officers of the AWU at the time, such as Ernie Grimes. For a time John Bannon was an industrial officer of the AWU and Barry Kavanagh was also an industrial officer of the AWU at the time.

The AWU and the clerks union did have one thing in common. In the late 1960s South Australia was a state with more federal awards than state awards. The industrial organisations that had state awards were in fact the AWU, which was the biggest union as far as the state Industrial Relations Commission was concerned, the shop assistants' union and the clerks union. So often I found myself in consultation with their industrial officers on how matters could best be dealt with by the state industrial commission.

It was in this time that four weeks annual leave came in and when annual leave loading was deliberated upon and awarded by the commission. It was in this time, too, that equal pay for work of equal value was first awarded by the federal industrial commission and these standards had to be converted into standards within the state jurisdictions as well. The AWU was a leading union in ensuring that no worker in South Australia was left behind and, in fact if at all possible, led the field this these matters nationally.

During all of that the eminence of Don Cameron permeated the scene. I have not had as close a relationship with him politically as my colleagues who have spoken in this debate, but I value what I thought was a generous and open friendship that he offered to me as a young industrial officer. He did so with a degree of decency and, I might say, sincerity that I have not really encountered very much in my political and industrial life. They were the hallmarks of Don Cameron. He was basically a very decent person and a very genuine Australian.

He was someone who always expressed, in whatever discussion he was involved in, true working class values. In the period of time in which he was an eminent figure in the labour movement he was a person best classed as a true progressive; someone interested in progressive reform at all times.

He was the president of the party at the time when the long run of the Playford government in South Australia came to an end and Frank Walsh became the first Labor Premier after Playford, followed by Don Dunstan. He presided as a strong figure in making sure that the ALP and the union movement was steered along sensible courses at a time in which massive change was occurring and a huge alteration in social values was occurring, too.

That was the role he played in my experience during the period of Whitlam government when his elder brother, Clyde Cameron, was a distinguished minister. Don would sometimes worry too much about issues. He always struck me as someone who was concerned to come to grips with what was really happening, get through all of the screen of the language, come to the kernel of the matter and see how it related to the working class values that he held. He would worry away at a problem until he got to that under standing. Then, when he got there, he would be a very eloquent spokesman for the interests of the people he represented, and usually that was the rank and file members of the AWU. I feel frankly that I am a bit privileged to be able to convey my condolences to such a great Australian.

talk.start.para: âSenator Bolkus did wish to be associated with this condolence motion. He is not able to be here. He was very keen that his association with this motion be made clear to the Senate.

speech.para: Can I indicate that he also had a very long relationship with Don Cameron. In the mid-1970s Senator Bolkus was at that time a non-senator and a young staffer employed by the then Senator Don Cameron. I would like to make it clear to the Senate that the same sentiments that my colleagues and I expressed when speaking to this condolence motion also go to Senator Bolkus.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

talk.start.para: âIt is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 13 June 1998 of the Reverend Gilbert William Arthur Duthie, a former member of the House of Representatives for the division of Wilmot in Tasmania from 1946 to 1975.
âPetitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: Petition to the Australian Senate
A CALL TO LABEL GENETICALLY ENGINEERED FOODS AND FOOD PRODUCTS
We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:
a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

Precedents which support of our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production: irradiated foods (internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt-reduced; free-range; vitamin-enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.

talk.start.para: Senator Stott Despoja(from 1,909 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows: That Australian citizens oppose social, legal and economic discrimination against people on the basis of their sexuality or transgender identity and that such discrimination is unacceptable in a democratic society.

Your petitioners request that the Senate should: pass the Australian Democrats Bill to make it unlawful to discriminate or vilify on the basis of sexuality or transgender identify so that such discrimination or vilification be open to redress at a national level.

talk.start.para: Senator Bartlett(from 10 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
(a) a proposal has been made by the Department of Transport to build a major no-curfew international airport in Sydney's western suburbs;
(b) airports and attendant infrastructure are a major source of air and noise pollution;
(c) Western Sydney already suffers from the worst air pollution in Australia;
(d) an additional airport in the Sydney airshed will only serve to greatly increase such pollution; and
(e) an airport in Sydney's west will harm the lifestyle and wellbeing of citizens living and working within the Sydney airshed.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate not pass any bill which would lead to the construction of any new airport within the Sydney airshed.

talk.start.para: Senator Bourne(from 32 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate, the deleterious effects of the Multilateral Agreement on Investment.
Your petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. Make available the draft text of the Agreement
2. Make a public statement about its intentions with regard to the signing of the MAI, detailing the beneficiaries of the Agreement, and accountability measures for all corporations
3. Not sign the MAI unless substantial amendment is made, including the observance of international agreements including environment, labour, health and safety and human rights standards
4. Extend the deadline for signing the MAI to enable full and proper public consultations to be held

talk.start.para: Senator Bourne(from 361 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament;
This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate, decisions by the Howard Government affecting the price and availability of medicines.

The decision to remove (delist) a number of drugs from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and also the decision to pressure people to switch to cheaper, older and less effective drugs, will disadvantage the less well off in our community who will not be able to afford the best most suitable drugs, the drugs their doctors have prescribed for them.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate recognises that these changes are unfair. We call on the Government to reverse these decisions immediately.

talk.start.para: Senator West(from 33 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that we, the citizens of regional Australia, call on the Senate to do everything possible to ensure that all Australian citizens have an equitable opportunity to be able to view the 1998 FIFA World Cup from France which is to be broadcast via the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) Network.

Regional Australians proudly belong to a multicultural nation and enjoy a widespread interest in international sport. We call on the Australian Senate to end the current discrimination that ensures that only metropolitan centres have access to the direct telecasting of one of the great sporting events of the world.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

talk.start.para: âI give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the provisions of paragraphs (5) to (7) of standing order 111 not apply to the following bills, allowing them to be considered during this period of sittings:
Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1998-99
Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1998-99
Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1998-99
Customs Legislation (Anti-dumping Amendments) Bill 1998
Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1998
Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Amendment Bill 1998
National Firearms Program Implementation Bill 1998
Passenger Movement Charge Amendment Bill 1998
Taxation Laws Amendment (Farm Management Deposits) Bill 1998
Taxation Laws Amendment (Landcare and Water Facility Tax Offset) Bill 1998
Wheat Marketing Legislation Amendment Bill 1998.
I also table statements of reasons justifying the need for these bills to be considered during this sitting and seek leave to have the statements incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The document read as followsâ
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1998-99
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1998-99
APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1998-99

Legislative authority for expenditure under the annual Appropriation Bills expires on 30 June each year and, unless new expenditure authority is in place by that time, activities of Government agencies funded through the annual Appropriation mechanism must cease.

The Appropriation Bills will provide legislative authority for expenditure in 1998-99. Passage of the Bills before 30 June 1998 is required to allow funds to be made available to all agencies from 1 July 1998, thereby ensuring continuity of program expenditure.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Finance and Administration)
CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (ANTI-DUMPING AMENDMENTS) BILL 1998
CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1998

The principal purpose of these Bills is to amend the Customs Act 1901 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 and repeal Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988 to implement the Government's announced reforms of the anti-dumping and countervailing systems in response to the Willett Report. The bills also make a number of minor and technical amendments to the anti-dumping provisions of the Customs Act 1901, including the removal of the local content rule from subsection 269T(2) for the purpose of determining whether goods are manufactured in Australia.
On 24 February 1998 the Government announced major changes to the administration of anti-dumping and countervailing investigations which will see investigations completed within a 155 day time frame.

This is to be achieved by the abolition of the current bifurcated investigation process in which an investigation progresses through two separate agencies, Customs and then the Anti-Dumping Authority (ADA). The ADA is to be abolished and Customs will have the sole responsibility for undertaking a comprehensive investigation and consultation process.

A new administrative appeal mechanism, independent of Customs, is to be.established which will provide all interested parties with a right to seek a speedy review of final finding as to whether to impose dumping or countervailing duties. Under current arrangements the only avenue open to an interested party seeking a review of a final finding is to institute proceedings in the Federal Court.

The Industry Task Force on Anti-Dumping, an informal grouping of major manufacturers and related associations, has expressed its strong support for the changes. The Task Force noted that the prompt implementation of the changes would remove the present uncertainty surrounding the administration of investigations, which has discouraged or delayed significant investment decisions to the detriment of the efficiency and competitiveness of Australian industry.

Introduction and passage of this package of legislation during the 1998 Winter sittings is desirable as it will ensure that the new amendments can begin by the scheduled commencement date of 1 July 1998 to the benefit of Australian industry.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs)
DATA-MATCHING PROGRAM (ASSISTANCE AND TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1998
The proposed Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Amendment Bill 1998 will remove the existing sunset clause in the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990.

The Bill needs to be introduced and passed in the 1998 Winter Sittings as the current sunset clause takes effect on 22 January 1999 and, if it were to come into effect, data-matching activities which help ensure the integrity of the social security system would have to be discontinued. This would result in a substantial negative impact on the forward estimates. Therefore, it is important to ensure that the Parliament considers the future of the data-matching program in 1998.
(Circulated by the authority of the Minister for Social Security)
NATIONAL FIREARMS PROGRAM IMPLEMENTATION BILL 1998

At its meetings of 10 May 1996, 17 July 1996 and 15 November 1996, the Australasian Police Ministers' Council (APMC) resolved that there be uniform national controls on firearms. The APMC also decided that there should be a buyback of prohibited firearms during an amnesty period of twelve months. The buyback was funded through an additional medicare levy. Compensation was paid by the States, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory, which were then reimbursed by the Commonwealth for compensation paid out and for some of the administrative costs associated with the buyback.

Norfolk Island has almost finalised its legislation to bring it into line with the APMC resolutions. The National Firearms Program Implementation Bill 1998 will make provision for the Commonwealth to fund that buyback out of remaining medicare levy funds in the same way as it did the States and mainland territories.

The Bill will also deal with the position on Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands. While it is thought that there may be few or no prohibited weapons on these islands, provision needs to be made for an amnesty period and a buyback by the Commonwealth.

The Bill is urgent because there should be provision for reimbursement by the Commonwealth before the Norfolk Island Administration starts making compensation payments for guns handed in. The amnesty period should commence in all three territories as soon as possible so that prohibited firearms do not remain in the community for any longer than necessary.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Justice)
PASSENGER MOVEMENT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1998
The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Passenger Movement Charge Act 1978 to increase the charge from $27 to $30 with effect from 1 January 1999.
The $3 increase was announced in the 1998-99 Budget.

In most cases, the charge is collected on behalf of the Commonwealth by international airlines at the time of sale of tickets for departures from Australia, in accordance with arrangements entered into under section 10 of the Passenger Movement Charge Collection Act 1978. It is not uncommon for such tickets to be sold up to 12 months in advance of the intended departure date. In order for airlines to be able to collect the increased amount on tickets sold between 1 July 1998 and 1 January 1999, for post 1 January 1999 departures, it is necessary that the amendments, with appropriate transitional arrangements, be in place before 1 July 1998.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs)
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (FARM MANAGEMENT DEPOSITS) BILL 1998
Purpose

The proposed Bill implements the new Farm Management Deposit (FMD) Scheme announced in the AgricultureâAdvancing Australia package. It replaces and/or amends a number of Acts, in particular the Loan (Income Equalisation Deposits) Act 1976 and the Income Tax assessment Act 1936.
The FMD Scheme will commercialise and modify the existing Income Equalisation Deposit (IED) and Farm Management Bond (FMB) schemes.
Reasons for urgency
Introduction and passage of the Bill in the 1998 Winter Sittings is sought to provide certainty to financial markets that an investment product and risk management tool will be available.

The FMD Scheme is a key plank of the AgricultureâAdvancing Australia packages It progresses agricultural policy by providing a mechanism for enhancing farmers' ability to manage risk and be financially self-reliant.

Under the legislative changes the prior IED and FMB Schemes will be made more commercially attractive and accessible for primary producers. The proposed amendments have the support of the financial community and rural sector. Expectations are high that the FMD Scheme will be available for the next financial year (1998-99). The FMD Scheme is a taxation based tool and uncertainty for potential investors will be increased if the Bill is not passed prior to the commencement of the taxation year.

The Department currently holds deposits in trust for approximately 9,500 clients in the IED and FMB Schemes. When the FMD Scheme commences these funds will have to be either withdrawn or transferred to financial institutions depending on the wishes of the individual client. Transfer and clarity for depositors would be simplified if notification could occur in line with a financial year changeover. Introduction and passage should occur prior to 30 June 1998 to allow notification of changes to depositors so transfers to the FMD Scheme could be mate for the 1998-99 financial year.
Effect of not passing

Delaying the passage of the proposed Bill until the Spring sittings would create uncertainty for farmers' investment decisions in the 1998-99 financial year and reduce their ability to achieve self-reliance in managing risk It would also make uncertain conversion of existing IED deposits to FMD deposits for the 1998-99 financial year. It may create difficulties for financial institutions and rural stakeholders who have provided considerable assistance in the development of this mechanism.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (LANDCARE AND WATER FACILITY TAX OFFSET) BILL 1998
Purpose of the proposed Bill:
This measure will implement the Government's election commitment that a rebate may be claimed for expenditure incurred on the prevention of land degradation.
The Bill contains the measure giving effect to an announcement made on 1 July 1997 by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.
Reasons for urgency:

The Minister announced that expenditure incurred after 30 June 1997 would be eligible for the rebate. To give effect to this policy for the 1997-98 income year. the Australian Taxation Office needs the law to be in place as soon as possible before the end of this financial year.
Result if Bill not dealt with in these sittings:

The measure will not be implemented in the time frame announced by the Government if the Bill is not passed during the 1998 Winter sitting period. Until legislation is in place, taxpayers will be uncertain about the intended operation of the law. The costs of administering the measure will increase with any delay in implementation.
(Circulated by authority of the Treasurer)
WHEAT MARKETING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1998

The purpose of the proposed bill is to implement the final stage in the restructure of the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) as a grower owned company from 1 July 1999. The first stage of this process, to allow the AWB to conduct its activities through wholly owned Corporations Law companies, was implemented by amendments to the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 last year. At that time the importance of a two stage approach to the restructure was accepted by the Senate and the need for further legislation was foreshadowed.

The proposed bill will terminate statutory marketing arrangements for wheat from 1 July 1999. A small statutory body will continue to undertake the AWB's current functions for the administration of wheat export controls. Ownership and control of a successor company to the AWB, to undertake the AWB's marketing and financing functions, will be passed to wheatgrowers by the issue of A Class shares and the conversion of equity in the Wheat Industry Fund (WIF) to B Class shares.
Introduction and passage for the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1998 in the 1998 Winter Sittings is being sought to provide certainty to financial markets about the longer term changes to the AWB.

Under the legislative changes agreed to last year the AWB's wholly owned subsidiary will have the opportunity to develop a track record and identity as a fully commercial (rather than a Government-backed body) and achieve a credit rating to enable it to operate after Government underwriting is withdrawn on 1 July 1999. The sooner that the future conversion of the AWB's subsidiary into a grower owned Corporations Law company is settled in legislation, the more likely it is that the company will be accepted by financial markets.

The AWB is one of Australia's largest borrowers on short term markets to finance advance and related payments for pool wheat delivered to it, and it is essential that the new grower company's access to funds for these purposes is not put in jeopardy. Legislation which clearly establishes the capital base of the new company as shares from the conversion of the WIF will remove any doubt that the WIF capital could be dissipated. This should build up the confidence of lenders dealing with the grower company.

Delaying passage of the proposed bill until the 1998 Spring Sittings could place unnecessary uncertainty over the final stage of privatisation which would be unsatisfactory from a commercial point of view.
(Circulated with the Authority of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: âI give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: (1) That the Senate notes:

(a) the observation expressed in the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Financial Institutions and Public Administration entitled Cultivating Competition: Inquiry into aspects of the National Competition Policy Reform Package , that there has been no major analysis of the broader socio-economic costs of the National Competition Policy; and

(b) that many voters in the 1998 Queensland election indicated that they were disillusioned with the unquestioning push by the major parties for economic reforms such as National Competition Policy without considering the broader impacts of such changes.

(2) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on the Socio-Economic Consequences of the National Competition Policy, be appointed to inquire into and report, on or before the first sitting day in 1999, on the following matters:

(a) the broader socio-economic consequences, including costs, of the National Competition Policy, as implemented by the Competition Policy Reform Act 1995 , including, but not limited to, the impact of the policy on:
(i) unemployment,
(ii) changed working conditions,
(iii) social welfare,
(iv) equity,
(v) social dislocation, and
(vi) environmental impacts; and
(b) the relative effect and variation in impact of the National Competition Policy on urban and rural and regional communities.

(3) That the committee consist of 7 senators, 3 nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 2 nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, 1 nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats and 1 nominated by the Greens (WA) or independent senators.

(4) That the quorum of the committee be 3 members with 1 representing the Government, 1 representing the Opposition and 1 representing either the Australian Democrats, the Greens (WA) or independent senators.
(5) That the committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that not all members have been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(6) That the chair of the committee be elected by and from the members of the committee.
(7) That the deputy chair of the committee be elected by and from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair.
(8) That the deputy chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting.
(9) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or deputy chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.

(10) That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations as it may deem fit.

(11) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the senators appointed to the subcommittee.

(12) That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee with the approval of the President.
(13) That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition

talk.start.para: âI give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the Senateâ

(a) recognises the vital contribution of the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition (AYPAC) to the development of policy affecting young Australians through its effective and comprehensive representation of young people;

(b) deplores the Government's short-sighted and mean-spirited replacement of AYPAC with a twice-yearly consultation with a select few young people, in contravention of a promise it made in 1996 to `improve the effectiveness of government in responding to the needs and concerns of young Australians by consulting directly with young Australians around the nation through formal representative organisations such as AYPAC';

(c) rejects the notion that a twice-yearly meeting of 50 young people without funding to carry out vital research into the effect of policies on young people and advise the Government on a year-round basis constitutes adequate consultation of young people and their concerns;
(d) condemns a reduction of almost $140 000 in funding to the representation of young people in policy development; and
(e) urges the Government to reverse this decision and restore funding to AYPAC so it can continue its invaluable work.

talk.start.para: âI give notice that, on 24 June 1998, I shall move:

speech.para: That the Senateâ
(a) notes moves within Indonesia and the United States of America to investigate the wealth and assets held by ex-president Suharto and his family and associates;

talk.start.para: âI give notice that, on 24 June, I shall move:

speech.para: That the Senateâ
(a) notes that:
(i) a report commissioned by the former Queensland State Government and prepared by the University of Queensland found a significant relationship between pig meat imports and domestic prices,
(ii) pig meat imports doubled in 1997,
(iii) prices received by Australian pork producers have collapsed to their lowest level in 30 years and are significantly below the cost of production,

(iv) the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) announced after the 1996 federal election that exceptional circumstances assistance would be available for rare and severe events not just for drought,

(v) the Minister released prior to the 1996 federal election a document entitled `Reviving the heartland' which stated under the heading `Exceptional Circumstances' that a collapse in world prices is an unforeseen event and therefore should be treated as exceptional and justifies special Government measures,
(vi) the surge in imports and the collapse on domestic prices have been accompanied by the fall in world prices for pig meat,
(vii) a combination of all the above factors has created a crisis in the industry which is well beyond normal management practices;
(viii) despite:
(a) the Howard Government's change in the definition of exceptional circumstances to include an unanticipated collapse in prices,
(b) the fact that research undertaken on behalf of the former Queensland Government has established a link between surging imports and collapsing prices, and
(c) the fact that pork producers incomes have collapsed,
the Minister has refused the industry desperately needed short-term help,
(ix) the Minister approved an application for special short-term assistance to farmers in the Monaro A district because of a range of factors, including lack of rainfall and pests, and
(x) the assistance is restricted to only 12 months because the region did not qualify for drought exceptional circumstances; and
(b) calls on the Minister to:
(i) immediately review his decision to reject exceptional circumstances assistance for pork producers; and
(ii) release all reports and related material on which he based his decisions:
(a) to reject the application for short-term help by the pork industry,
(b) to reject the application for exceptional circumstances assistance to the Monaro region in December 1997, and
(c) to approve the application for exceptional circumstances assistance to farmers in the area known as Monaro A in March 1998.

talk.start.para: âI give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the following matter be referred to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities for inquiry and report by 24 July 1998:
Whether there needs to be reform of the law regulating industrial relations and/or corporations so that it appropriately and adequately deals with the following issues:
(a) the trend for companies to declare themselves insolvent in order to avoid paying employees their legitimate entitlements;
(b) the trend to use shell companies to avoid the normal contractual obligations arising from the employer/employee relationship;
(c) protecting workers' entitlements in the transmission of businesses;
(d) corporate avoidance or evasion of Workplace Relations Act protections;
(e) protecting workers' entitlements in circumstances of privatisation or contracting out;
(f) protecting against manipulation of corporate structures to avoid employee rights and entitlements;
(g) protections for workers employed by insolvent employers;
(h) the inter-relationship between the Corporations Law, the Workplace Relations Act and awards and industrial agreements; and
(i) minimising the adverse effects on employees of insecure employment forms.

talk.start.para: âI give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the Senate notes:
(a) the two proposed magnesite mines and value-added processing by Crest Resources near West Takone and Golden Triangle near Savage River on Tasmania's north-west coast;
(b) that the north-west coast is a region of Tasmania which has had significant industry restructuring, high unemployment and net population decline;
(c) the projects will be appropriately assessed for their impact on the environment under relevant State laws;
(d) the attempt by the Tasmanian Greens' State member Ms Peg Putt to mislead the Tasmanian and Australian public by claiming the caves and karsts would be threatened by any mining proposals;

(e) the rebuttal of such claims by Mr Bevis Dutton of the Savage River Caving Club and geomorphologist Mr Kevin Kiernan, the author of a study of the karsts, which Ms Putt incorrectly quoted, rejecting her claims;
(f) Mr Kiernan's view that he did not believe there was a conflict with mining in the area given commonsense, goodwill and careful planning;
(g) Ms Putt's failure to apologise for misleading the public;
(h) Ms Putt's condemnation of the proposals before a pre-feasibility study is carried out; and
Senator Brown interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âShe should, Senator Brown. I will take that interjection.
âShe hasn't misled anybody.
âShe has grossly lied to the Tasmanian and Australian publicâand you know that very, very well, Senator Brown.
âBring this on.
âIt will be a ripper of a debate.
âYou're the one who'll get ripped.
âI note Senator Brown's constant interjection and interruption in opposing a very worthwhileâ
âOrder! Senator Sherry, you should not be making an offensive comment about a state member of parliament.
âThat's right.
âAre you asking me to withdraw the comment, Mr Acting Deputy President?
âI think you should, yes.
âI will withdraw the comment that she lied, but it was a terminological inexactitude and she did grossly mislead the public. To conclude:

speech.para: (i) Ms Putt's admission in reference to the general area that, `It has been quarried and timber harvested in the past, but it has regained a high quality wilderness'.

talk.start.para: âI give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the Senateâ
(a) notes:
(i) that the Victorian Treasury recently overturned a prohibition on electricity companies offering power from renewable sources at extra cost,

talk.start.para: âMr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to move a motion to exempt a bill from standing order 111.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the provisions of paragraphs 5 to 7 of standing order 111 not apply to the Health Care (Appropriation) Bill 1998, allowing it to be considered during this period of sittings.

I also table a statement of reasons justifying the need for this bill to be considered during this sittings and seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard . Copies of the statement have been circulated in the chamber.
Leave granted.
The statement read as followsâ
HEALTH CARE (APPROPRIATION) BILL 1998

The Bill will appropriate funds to make a Commonwealth contribution for the period of 5 years starting on 1 July 1998 to the cost of health and emergency services provided by hospitals in the States and Territories; and to fund projects designed to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of, or to reduce demand for, such services, or to improve patient outcomes from such services.
The Bill requires introduction and passage in the same sitting to ensure the continuity of Commonwealth funding for public hospitals ant related services.

If the Bill is not dealt with in one sitting there will be no legislative basis to allow payments for health and emergency services provided by hospitals in the States and Territories, meaning States and Territories could lose up to 10 per cent of their revenue base.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Health and Family Services)

talk.start.para: âThe question is that the motion be agreed to. Those of that opinion, say aye; those against, say no. I think the ayes have it.
âSenator Brown, do you have some problems?
âby leaveâYes, I do. Which motion was just put to the Senate?
âThe motion was to exempt a certain bill.
âI thought it was a notice of motion. Obviously, it is not a notice of motion. If it is a notice of motion, then weâ
âLeave was granted to move the motion, and we voted on the motion.

âI am sorry, but that is not the way we should be dealing with these kinds of motions. To incorporate the terms of reference of something we are actually being asked to vote on right now is not the way to put things through the Senate. I am sorry, but I certainly do not give leave to be acting in that way; that is not the way to get your program through at this time of the year.
âYou actually did give leave.

âMr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. While the opposition will be voting for the exemption, I think the Senate was confused as to what was put. There was some discussion between you and the clerk, and I think it was unclear to some of the senators whether we were voting on leave to move the motion or to put the motion. I think it would be in the interests of the Senate if we actually retraced our steps a bit and were clear what we were doing.
âLeave was sought to move the motion and, once leave was granted, we then proceeded.

âMr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. During the seeking of leave, the minister said that the statement of reasons had been circulated in the Senate. However, I, for one, had not received it at that time; I have since.
âIt is on your desk.

âThrough you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to Senator O'Chee, it is on your desk over there; it was not over here, but it was delivered consequently. It is quite untoward for us to have been asked to vote on that motion without having had the arguments put to us. I ask that the vote be resubmitted to the Senate if the minister would be so good as to permit that. If not, I ask that my vote against the motion be recorded.

âby leaveâSenator Margetts, I am advisedâand it might assist you and, in particular, people reading the Hansard or people listening at the moment who may think a swiftie has been pulledâthat this matter was raised at the whips meeting this morning and that you had a representative at the meeting. It was indicated then that the government intended to do this at this time today. Subsequent to the meeting, both your office and Senator Brown's office separately were rung and advised in relation to this matter.
âI was not in my office. I haven't been spoken to because I was in the Senate.

âAs I was saying, the matter was raised at the whips' meeting. Senator Margetts had a representative there. Subsequent to the whips' meeting, both senators were rung to see if there was a problem. One senator is now indicating in the chamber by way of interjection, having already had the liberty to speak himself, that he simply has not been in his office. That is regrettable, but I am simply trying to indicate that the government has had good intentions and followed the appropriate process for when this sort of change is sought to be made, and that is, raise it first thing in the morning and put it on the Senate red.

âby leaveâMr Acting Deputy President, I suggest it would be more useful if this were done as a notice of motion, and then we would have a little time. I am sorry about the confusion, I was not able to go to the whips' meeting today. Instead of just getting something in your hand and being expected to decide on the spot, it would be more reasonable to put it as a notice of motion and then we can vote on it after we have actually had time to consider it.

âby leaveâOne of the difficulties with that, Senator Margetts, is that the reason it was raised at the whips' meeting this morning is that there is a possibility that we will want to deal with this tonight. That was the whole purpose of raising it this morning. I am sorry if your representative did not convey the matter back to you, but that was the purpose of early notice being given today.
âThe motion has been carried and, unless it is the wish of the Senate that the vote be recommitted, we stand by that.

âMr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Both of us asked whether that could be traced back to its first stages because of the confusionâI do not think that is an unreasonable thing. Because our response related to that level of confusion, we are asking, quite reasonably, that leave be asked for again so we can respond based on our now ascertaining what the situation is. I am suggesting that it is reasonable that this be put as a notice of motion and dealt with accordingly.
âSenator Margetts, I can only put the motion again by order of the Senate.
âI asked for leaveâ
âHowever, if you wish, you can have your vote recorded against the motion.

âMr Acting Deputy President, I wonder if you might just ask the Senate if they would give leave for it to be recommitted? You have not actually asked the Senate if they would do that. It is happening all the time in the Senate; people say, `Can we go back to that?' I would appreciate it if you would actually ask that question before saying, `No, we can't go back to it.'
âIf that is what you are asking to do, can you seek leave and put it formally, and I will accept it.
âThank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I seek leave for the issue to be recommitted from the start.
âIs leave granted?

âMr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The issue of leave for the motion has already been dealt with. My understanding is that if the request is that the motion be put to the voteâ
âBe recommitted.
âYes. If the actual motion itself be voted upon, we are quite happy to accept that. It is just that the inexactitude of the terminology used by Senator Margetts does require me to clarify it.
âSenator Margetts, could you clarify your position? Are you seeking leave for the motion to be put or to go right back to the beginning?

âThe words I used were that we start from the beginning. I do not know how to make that any clearer. If Senator O'Chee wants to refuse leave, that is for him to say. I would like to seek leave that the leave sought by Senator Vanstone be put again because of the confusion on this side whether we were being asked to vote on an issue on which we have only just received the information in our hands.

âPerhaps we can try to short-circuit this. Senator Margetts, this is very difficult, especially when people are trying to raise things in the appropriate order. There was a meeting this morning which you had a representative attending and I am sorry if your representative has not kept you informed and consequently you come to this issue, as you say, freshâab initio, if you likeâand do not know what is going on. Will it assist you if we agree to withdraw what we have done and give notice that at a later hour we will move it? That in a sense gives notice of a motion but it still will allow it to come on if the need we were anticipating this morning arises that we might need to discuss it later today. Would that be satisfactory?
âIt is an improvement.
âIs leave granted for that course of action to be followed? There being no objection, it is so granted.
âI will seek leave at a later hour to move that. Are you happy, Senator Margetts? The whole place is running according to your agenda.

âI do not actually appreciate the patronising. It is the truth that we have a whips' meeting in the morning. It is also the truth that good government does not wait until you are making the vote to put that into the hands of senators. If there was an agreement at the whips' meeting, there was a necessity, I would have thought, to provide this earlier than right on the time the vote was taken. I do not think the patronising is particularly appreciated.
âThat is why you were rung, Senator.
