occurred outside Canberra since March 1996; and (b) Where has the training taken place.

talk.start.para: âThe Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The following table gives details of the training courses which were organised by the Department held outside Canberra since March 1996:

entry.para: People Management and Development Section Team Building

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 6 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the Tasmanian Government responded to the offer from the Commonwealth in providing a third of the funding for construction of an access road to the port area of Devonport, Tasmania, under the Roads of National Importance program; if not, (a) has a counter offer been put to the Commonwealth by the Tasmanian Government for construction; (b) what are the terms of the counter offer.

(2) If an agreement has been reached between the State Government, Local Government and the Commonwealth, when is the physical work of construction set to commence and when is it planned to be completed.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) No. A formal proposal has not yet been received. However officer discussions have been under way for some time to develop a satisfactory proposal.
(a) No.
(b)Not applicable.

(2) Until a Project Proposal Report is received by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, no indication can be given on the likely commencement and completion of construction of the project.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 12 March 1998:

question.para: With reference to the Brisbane Airport:

(1) (a) What arrangements are there governing the minimum allowable altitude for aircraft passing over residential areas during take off and landing on each runway; and (b) have these arrangements been altered since 2 March 1996.
(2) For each month since January 1996, on how many occasions has each runway limit been breached.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The operation of aircraft in Australia is covered by the Civil Aviation Regulations. However, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) advise that the Regulations do not prescribe minimum altitudes during take-off and landing over residential areas. Altitude limitations during take-off and landing are not feasible because of the nature of the activity.

However, CASA requires aircraft departing and landing at airports, including Brisbane, to follow published procedures for minimum gradients. Aircraft departing from airports are required to comply with a minimum climb gradient of 3.3% from the departure end of the runway, unless a steeper gradient is necessary for obstacle clearance. Aircraft approaching to land are required to follow a 3 degree approach path to the runway, beginning from an approach altitude which is dependent on whether the aircraft is following visual or instrument procedures.
(b) No.
(2) Not applicable.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 26 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the Australia New Zealand Food Authority (ANZFA) recommended to the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council a draft standard to the Food Standards Code for the labelling of foods using gene technology; if so, does the draft standard prescribe mandatory labelling for foods containing new or altered genetic materials; if not, why not.

(2) (a) What does the term `substantial equivalence' mean when used to describe foods containing new or altered genetic materials; and (b) what does `conventional counterparts in a characteristic or property of a food' mean as it relates to `substantial equivalence'.

(3) What are the scientific principles relied on by ANZFA to justify its decision that it was not necessary to prescribe mandatory labelling of foods that are substantially equivalent to their conventional counterparts.

(4) What public health factors were relied on by ANZFA to justify its decision that it was not necessary to prescribe mandatory labelling of foods that are substantially equivalent to their conventional counterparts.
(5) How is it `more restrictive than necessary to achieve a legitimate outcome'.
(6) What are Australia's obligations to the World Trade Organisation (WTO) Agreements with respect to foods containing new or altered genetic material.

(7) Is the draft standard prescribing mandatory labelling for foods containing new or altered genetic materials necessary to comply with the minimum requirements of the WTO Agreement; if so, how; if not, why not.
(8) How would the draft standard be inconsistent with Australian policies if it was not implemented.
(9) Why is labelling of foods containing new or altered genetic materials which are substantially equivalent not useful information for consumers.
(10) Is all information currently required to be included on labels useful information for consumers; if so, how.
(11) Is there any information currently required to be included on labels which is not useful information for consumers.
(12) Does ANZFA prescribe other standards which cannot be enforced; if so, which ones; if not, why not.

(13) Are there any other circumstances where ANZFA has decided not to prescribe a standard because it is regarded as not practicable; if so, what are these circumstances; if not, why is food labelling for foods containing new or altered genetic materials a special circumstance.

(14) Is there any data available to ANZFA which shows consumer preferences for labelling of foods containing new or altered genetic materials; if so, what is it; if not, does ANZFA intend to obtain this data.
(15) How is `substantial equivalence' determined when used to describe foods containing new or altered genetic materials.
(16) Is a food derived from a plant or animal which contains new or altered genetic materials the same as food derived from a plant or animal which does not contain new or altered genetic materials.

(17) Does genetic engineering have the same outcome as traditional breeding techniques for food crops and animals; if so, what procedures would be undertaken to introduce genes from one phyla into another phyla using traditional breeding techniques.
(18) Is genetic engineering a precise manner for transferring genetic material from one genome to another for food crops and animals.

(19) Where genetic engineering is applied for transferring genetic material from one genome to another for food crops and animals, is the level of expression of the inserted genetic material predictable.

(20) Where genetic engineering is applied for transferring genetic material from one genome to another for food crops and animals, does this procedure occur at low frequencies; if so, what is the range of frequencies.

(21) (a) Where genetic engineering is applied for transferring genetic material from one genome to another for food crops and animals, are all integrated genetic materials stable; and (b) how is this determined.

(22) Where genetic engineering is applied for transferring genetic material from one genome to another for food crops and animals, are marker genes included in the new or altered genetic materials; if so, are all these genes harmless to humans and are there any other environmental consequences.

(23) (a) Where genetic engineering is applied for transferring genetic material from one genome to another for food crops and animals, are any of these marker genes antibiotic resistance genes; and (b) is this important.

(24) Where genetic engineering is applied for transferring genetic material from one genome to another for food crops and animals, is there any possibility of horizontal gene transfer into the genome of humans.
(25) Are there some pleotropic effects of genetic engineering of food products which are not considered in determining `substantial equivalence'.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The draft standard prescribes mandatory labelling for any food that is or contains components produced using gene technology containing new or altered genetic material and not substantially equivalent in any characteristic or property to a conventionally consumed food.

(2)â(4) and (15)â(25) In the context of the draft standard, substantially equivalent in regard to a characteristic or property of the food means that the nutritional and compositional value of the food falls within the normal range for similar foods that are or contain foods derived by conventional breeding methods. This includes that the food does not contain higher levels of anti-nutritional factors or natural toxicants or introduced allergenic factors and does not lead to the food having a different pattern of dietary exposure.

A determination of substantial equivalence can be carried out at the level of the food source or at the level of the specific food product. This involves a consideration of the molecular characterisation of the new food source; phenotypic characteristics of the new food source in comparison to an appropriate comparator already in the food supply; and the compositional analysis of the new food source or the specific food product in comparison to the comparator. The comparison may be made to the parental line/strain and/or other edible lines/strains of the same species, or it can build on a comparison of the derived food product (eg, protein, carbohydrate, fat) with a comparable conventional food product.

The application of the principle of substantial equivalence to safety assessment enables the public health and safety risks of the food to be characterised by reference to the known public health and safety characteristics of its conventionally bred counterpart. All relevant effects are taken into account in determining `substantial equivalence*.

(5)â(6) Australia is party to two World Trade Organisation (WTO) Agreements which are relevant to foods. The Agreement on Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures (SPS) addresses measures necessary to protect human, animal or plant life or health. The Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT) addresses technical regulations and standards to ensure the quality of exports; protection of human, animal or plant life or health, or the environment; or for the prevention of deceptive practices. These agreements oblige Australia to ensure that its regulations and standards are applied consistently, are based on sound data and are no more trade restrictive than is necessary to achieve a legitimate objective.

(7) The draft standard is consistent with the requirements of the WTO SPS and TBT agreements in that it provides a level of consumer protection for safety and deception, consistent with other existing food standards, without imposing undue restrictions on the movement of goods in trade.

(8) There is currently no specific regulation of foods from gene technology. If the draft standard is not implemented then consumers would not be assured that foods from gene technology had been assessed and found to be safe before they were sold and that where these foods were compositionally or nutritionally different they would be informed.

(9) The issue of whether the labelling of foods containing new or altered genetic material which is substantially equivalent is, or is not, useful information for consumers has been assessed by ANZFA in the context of all potential sources of information likely to be available to consumers. ANZFA is concerned to ensure that a comprehensive approach is taken to ensure consumers have access to adequate information which would allow them to make informed choices.

In regard to the value of mandatory labelling, ANZFA has given particular attention to the comprehensive labelling requirements enacted in the European Union. This regulation allows "may contain" labelling statements where the presence of a genetically modified component is uncertain. ANZFA has questioned whether the statement "may contain" is of value as it has the potential to be required on a very large number of foods. Such a statement may be of value to the extent that a consumer totally opposed to the processes of gene technology could avoid any food bearing the appropriate label. However, for a consumer wishing to make a choice on the basis of perceived relative benefits of a food produced using gene technology compared to a conventional counterpart, or between two foods produced using gene technology, the statement "may contain" is of little value. In addition, it is likely that a number of foods bearing this label would in fact contain no genetically modified component and, in that respect, such labelling has the potential to be deceptive. Therefore, to introduce full mandatory labelling, resulting in the proliferation of such "may contain" labelling statements, could in fact distract a consumer from making an informed choice.

(10)â(13) ANZFA is currently undertaking a comprehensive review of the Australian Food Standards Code. In developing or reviewing food standards, the ANZFA must have regard to the objectives outlined in section 10 of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Act 1991.

Consistent with these statutory objectives, the review will, where possible: reduce the level of prescriptiveness of standards to facilitate innovation by allowing wider permission on the use of ingredients and additives, but with consideration of the possible increased need for consumer information; develop standards which are easier to understand and make amendment more straight forward; replace standards which regulate individual foods with standards that apply across all foods or a range of foods; consider the possibility of industry codes of practice as an alternative to regulation; and facilitate harmonisation of food standards between Australia and New Zealand.

The review will also be carried out in accordance with the competition policy principles which have been adopted by the Council of Australian Governments. These principles require the review of all business regulation to remove unnecessary obstacles to competition, and an assessment of the social, environmental and economic impacts as well as the impacts on health of proposed regulation on all affected sectors of the community.

Through this review ANZFA will ensure that mandatory food labelling is only required for information which has been assessed as necessary, having regard to voluntary labelling and to the other sources of information available to consumers. ANZFA will also ensure that standards are enforceable and that any standards which cannot be enforced are deleted.

(14) ANZFA is aware of a number of surveys undertaken in Australia and overseas in which a majority of consumers have expressed a desire for foods produced using gene technology to be labelled. ANZFA considers that it is the primary responsibility of industry to provide consumers with information on such foods where these are substantially equivalent to their conventionally bred counterparts and is committed to working with industry and consumers to facilitate the provision of such information.

(16)â(17) There is no intrinsic reason why a food derived from a plant or animal which contains new or altered genetic material should not be the same as food derived from a plant or animal which does not contain new or altered genetic materials. Any differences will result from the specific genetic material present and the way in which it is expressed. Traditional breeding techniques would not normally result in the introduction of genetic material from one phyla to another, although, wide-crossing and similar techniques can be used to transfer genetic material between species which do not normally interbreed.

(18)â(19) Genetic engineering provides a means for introducing a precise sequence of DNA into a genome. The exact position of each insertion and the level of expression will vary from insertion to insertion. Screening is used to determine which insertions are then selected for further commercial development.

(20) The frequency of successful transfer of genetic material from one genome to another will depend upon the techniques used, the species to which the technique is applied and the level of expression of inserted genetic material desired.

(21) Inserted genetic material is not necessarily stable. Stability in a commercial product is ensured by screening prior to approval for release of a genetically modified organism. Only organisms containing material found to be stable are approved by the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee (GMAC) for release into the environment.

(22)â(23) The use of marker genes and the types of marker genes selected will depend upon the techniques used and the organisms involved. The ANZFA draft standard will ensure that any food that is or contains components produced using gene technology will be assessed for safety before it can be sold. This assessment will include consideration of any marker genes present, including possible antibiotic resistance marker genes. The assessment of any implications for the environment is undertaken by GMAC prior to release.

(24) Although there is a theoretical possibility of horizontal gene transfer from foods into the genome of humans, in practice such transfers do not occur. Furthermore, there is no evidence that the probability of such transfer from a food made from or containing a genetically modified organism would be any greater than from food made from conventionally bred organisms.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 30 March 1998:

question.para: With reference to page 67 of the 1996-97 annual report of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority (ANZFA):
(1) Does ANZFA undertake `special projects'; if so, what special projects are currently being undertaken.
(2) What `special projects' were undertaken in the 1995-96 financial year.
(3) What monies were provided to ANZFA for these `special projects' in the financial years 1995-96 and 1996-97.
(4) (a) Who or what provided these monies; and (b) what did they receive in return for these monies.
(5) What does `other' in `other revenues' mean.
(6) What `other' are currently being undertaken.
(7) What `other' were undertaken in the 1995-96 financial year.
(8) What monies were provided to ANZFA for these `other' in the financial years 1995-96 and 1996-97.
(9) (a) Who or what provided these monies; and (b) what did they receive in return for these monies.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The term `special projects' refers to one-off tasks that ANZFA is required to undertake, however, these `special projects' are directly relevant to the core business activities of ANZFA. Both internal and external auditors, together with the Authority's finance staff, agreed that a separate revenue category be developed due to the materiality of the revenue involved.

There are currently two special projects: (1) participation in regional activities relevant to food standards; and (2) review of the Model Food Act 1980, review of State and Territory Food Acts and to develop a (new) nationally uniform Food Act. (2) Initial development of the Australian Food Safety Information Network (AFSIN) on behalf of the State and Territory health authorities.
(3) During the 1995-96 financial year, $96,800 was provided to ANZFA for the initial development of AFSIN.

During the 1996-97 financial year, $51,000 was provided to ANZFA for the initial development of AFSINâthis funding remained outstanding in the previous financial year; $126,126 was provided for the regional project; and $160,000 was provided for the Model Food Act project.

(4) (a) AFSIN funding was provided by the States and Territories in the 1995-96 financial year. Participation in regional activities was provided by AusAID and Model Food Act project funding was provided by the Commonwealth Department of Health and Family Services in the 1996-97 financial year.

(b) The AFSIN funding was used to develop the architecture of an ORACLE database. Each State and Territory Health Authority was provided with a stand alone computer which connected to the database. The State and Territory Health Authority users were encouraged to enter test data into the database and were provided with technical advice and assistance centrally from ANZFA.

The regional project funds were used to undertake a study of regional product standards initiatives and to develop a regional development program under the auspices of The APEC Standards and conformance sub-committee.
Model Food Act funding was used to develop a model for a nationally uniform food legislation.

(5) `Other' in `other revenues' is comprised of small differing types of income, individually immaterial to disclose separately. `Other' includes the following specific items: public register access chargesâthe public can request access to certain Authority records; car parking feesârecovery of costs for staff who park their private vehicles in ANZFA leased parking bays; Comcare reimbursements; refunds/recoveries from various organisations for travel and salary costs for staff who speak at conferences and seminars; and Memorandum of Understanding with the Department of Health and Family Services for the provision of a Nutritional Analysisâthis accounts for 9% of 1996-97 `other revenue'.

(6) `Other' for the 1997-98 financial year includes Comcare reimbursements, car parking fees, public register access charges and refunds/recover ies from external bodies for travel and salaries for staff attending seminars and conferences etc.

(7) `Other' for the 1995-96 financial year includes Comcare reimbursements, car parking fees, public register access charges and refunds/recoveries from external bodies for travel and salaries for staff attending seminars and conferences etc.

(8) In the 1995-96 and 1996-97 financial years the `other' in `other revenue' comprised immaterial amounts of differing types of recovery payments for services provided. These items included the following specific items:
. Public register access charges (1995-96â$1,713; 1996-97â$2,045);
. Car parking recovery from staff (1995-96â$8,180; 1996-97â$9,016);
. Speakers fees (1996-97 onlyâ$11,046); and
. Refunds/recoveries from external bodies for staff attending conferences and seminars and accounting transfers make up the remaining funds.
(9) (a) The `user' of the service provided these monies.
(b) In return for monies paid the `user' received various outcomes ranging from utilisation of a car parking space to access to the public register.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 7 April 1998:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact the salt-affected areas of Western Australia the worst affected region for salinity in Australia, increased from 264,000 hectares in 1982 to 1,804 million hectares in 1996.

(2) Does the Government agree that, if no action is taken, future estimates of the potential areas in Western Australia vulnerable to salinity degradation are as high as 6,109 million hectares, according to the Australian Magazine of 21 and 22 March 1998 quoting State and Federal Government documents, National Dryland Salinity Program and Western Australian salinity statement.
(3) What resources are being allocated, and what policies and programs have been adopted, by the Federal Government to combat the problems of salinity and land degradation in Western Australia.

(4) (a) How much money has the Federal Government allocated to spend on combating the problems of salinity and land degradation in Western Australia; and (b) what does this repre sents in cents per hectare, based on 1,804 million hectares being salinity-affected.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1)â(2) I agree that it is a serious problem. I understand the increase in areas affected in WA to be from 264,000 hectares in 1982 to 1,804,000 hectares in 1996, not an increase to 1,804 million hectares. I understand the potential area in WA vulnerable to dryland salinity degradation is 6,109,000 hectares, not 6,109 million hectares.
(3) The Western Australian State Salinity Action Plan is an agreed priority in the Natural Heritage Trust Partnership Agreement between the Commonwealth and Western Australia.

(4) (a) and (b) In 1997-98 the Commonwealth Government committed over $23 million of Natural Heritage Trust funds from programs such as Bushcare, Landcare, Rivercare and Farm Forestry to WA. These funds are being expended on projects and activities predominantly in the south west of WA where the Salinity Action Plan is targeted. Given that funding available under the Natural Heritage Trust has been significantly increased for 1998-99 I would expect that the level of Commonwealth commitment to addressing salinity problems in WA will be even greater in the next year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 15 April 1998:

question.para: (1) When did the New South Wales Government first apply for drought exceptional circumstances (DEC) assistance for the Monaro district.

(2) (a) When did the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Committee (RASAC) inspect the region; (b) when was the RASAC report provided to the Minister; and (c) when did the Minister advise the New South Wales Government of his decision.
(3) If the application was rejected, what was the basis of the rejection.

(4) Were subsequent applications made by the New South Wales Government if so: when were they lodged; (b) when did RASAC inspect the region; (c) when did it report to the Minister; and (d) when was the New South Wales Government advised of the Minister's decision.
(5) What was the basis of the decision in respect of the application.
(6) (a) What area was covered by the New South Wales Government's successful application for DEC for the Monaro district; and (b) how many farm families were in the area covered by the application.
(7) (a) What percentage of the area covered in the application was approved for DEC assistance; and (b) how many farm families are in that area.

(8) (a) How many farm families have qualified for farm household assistance and business support; (b) how many families failed to qualify for family and/or business support; and (c) on what basis was each application rejected.

(9) With reference to a statement by the Minister, in answer to a question without notice on 7 April 1998, that more people receive more assistance than was possible under the arrangements in place under the previous Government, with the exception of the extension of the recovery period, to what other variations to the previous DEC arrangements was the Minister referring.
(10) (a) How many people are currently in receipt of DEC assistance; and (b) what is the average value of that assistance.
(11) (a) How many people would have been in receipt of DEC assistance under the program administered by the previous Government; and (b) what would have been the average value of the assistance.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The New South Wales Government first wrote to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy on 6 August 1997 to request DEC assistance for the Monaro district.
(2) (a) RASAC inspected the Monaro region on 15 September 1997.

(b) On 19 September 1997, the New South Wales Government requested that the Monaro application no longer be considered under DEC, and instead be assessed under general exceptional circumstances (EC). On 16 October 1997, Minister Anderson wrote to the New South Wales Minister for Agriculture requesting clarification of the event for which EC assistance was being sought and requested that additional information to support the application be provided promptly. RASAC provided its report to Minister Anderson on 21 October 1997. On 11 November 1997, the New South Wales Government provided additional information for consideration in the assessment of their application. On 15 December 1997, the Government decided not to provide EC support to the Monaro Region but requested that RASAC reassess the region in early 1998.
(c) Minister Anderson advised the New South Wales Government of this decision in writing on 31 December 1997.
(3) The government accepted RASAC's findings that the specified area of the Cooma region did not meet the criteria for EC as
. overall rainfall for the last three years had been near average;
. pasture is naturally of poor quality but could be improved;
. weed infestation was similar to that in the Greater Monaro Region; and
. livestock numbers had declined but no more so than in other areas of New South Wales.
(4) (a) On 30 January 1998, the New South Wales Government provided Minister Anderson with supporting information for the reassessment of the Monaro region.

(b) RASAC inspected the Monaro Region on 2 February 1998. On 5 February, the New South Wales Government amended the boundaries of the Monaro Region application area (henceforth known as Monaro Region A), increasing its area by approximately one third. In addition, on 9 February 1998 it was requested that an additional area (known as Monaro Region B) to the south of the original Monaro application area be considered for EC assistance.
(c) RASAC reported to Minister Anderson on 18 February 1998 for Monaro Region A and 3 April 1998 for Monaro Region B.
(d) The New South Wales Government was advised of the Commonwealth Government's decision in relation to Monaro Region A on 3 March 1998 and for Monaro Region B on 8 April 1998.

(5) Conditions in Monaro Region A were considered to have deteriorated since RASAC's previous visit. An EC was declared based on the impact of a succession of adverse climatic and biotic events. Monaro Region B was declared in DEC as it met all criteria including the threshold meteorological criterion.
(6) (a) Monaro Region A is bound on:
. the east from Cooma to Numeralla Road to the Numeralla River;
. the south along the Numeralla River to the Kydra Nimmitabel Road. East to the junction with the Snowy Mountains Highway at Nimmitabel;
. the west to the Monaro Highway junction;
. west down to the Monaro Highway to Bibbenluke;
. west on Bukalong Road to Bukalong Creek;

. south and west downstream of Bukalong Creek to Bombala River to the Delegate River to the Snowy River to the eastern boundary of Kosciusko National Park, following the Kosciusko National Park north west to Pot Hole Creek;

. north up Pot Hole Creek to the watershed on Beloka Range. Following the watershed along the Beloka and Barney's Ranges to the Berridale Rocky Plain Road at the Gap east along the road to Wullwye Creek;
. north up Wullwye Creek to Berridale Middlebank Road, at Growlers Gully then north to Middlebank; and
. east on road from Middlebank to Cooma.
Monaro Region B:
. extends south along the Monaro Highway from Bibbenluke (the boundary of Region A) to Bombala, continuing south along the Monaro Highway to Little Plains River;
. continuing south downstream along the Little Plains River to the NSW border at Bendoc Upper;
. north west along the NSW border to the boundary of Kosciusko National Park; and
. north along the east boundary of Kosciusko National Park to the junction of the Snowy River (the boundary of Region A).

(b) It was reported by the New South Wales Government that there are approximately 150â160 landholders in Monaro Region A and 78 landholders in Monaro Region B whose land has a carrying capacity of 1 500 DSE or greater.
(7) (a) 100 per cent of the areas covered in the two applications were approved for either EC or DEC assistance.
(b) See answer to 6 (b) above.
(8) (a) To date, there are 39 applications which have been approved for Exceptional Circumstances
Relief Payment (ECRP) in Monaro regions A and B. Of the 12 applications received for DEC Interest Rate Subsidy (IRS) there is only one approval to date.
(b) As at 27 April 1998, there had been 3 unsuccessful claims under the ECRP. No DEC IRS applications have been rejected to date; eleven are still under consideration.
(c) All ECRP applications which have been unsuccessful failed due to the off-farm assets test.

(9) In addition to Drought Exceptional Circumstances, the Government gives recognition to Exceptional Circumstances that are beyond the scope of normal risk management, and that in these circumstances it is in the national interest for the Government to provide assistance.

A new Exceptional Circumstances Relief Payment (ECRP), equivalent to the previous Drought Relief Payment, has been established and is available to eligible farmers in declared Exceptional Circumstances. In assessing Exceptional Circumstances there is no meteorological trigger criterion.
This is in addition to an extension of the recovery period for Drought Exceptional Circumstances, from six to 12 months.
(10) (a) As at 1 May 1998, there were 2,743 farmers across Australia in receipt of ECRP. As at 31 March 1998, there were 1,093 DEC IRS recipients.
(b) During April 1998 the average value of ECRP assistance paid to each farm family was $1,010 per month.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Health and Family Services: Research
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1143)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 17 April 1998:

question.para: (1) Given that nine departments have now answered in full the questions placed on notice on 16 October 1997 (questions on notice 902-916, Senate Notice Paper of 21 October 1997) relating to qualitative and quantitative research, on what basis was it decided that the department would not authorise the money, time and effort involved to assemble the information required to provide and answer to the question.
(2) What qualitative or quantitative research has been undertaken by the department and its agencies since 3 March 1996.
(3) (a) What was the nature of the research undertaken, (sample sizes, questionnaire length, evaluation); and (b) to whom were the results of the research available.
(4) In each instance, which firm or firms have been engaged to undertake this work.
(5) In each instance what has been the cost of the work undertaken.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The decision was taken as it would have required considerable money, time and resources to provide a full answer to the question and, in the interest of efficient utilisation of departmental resources, I was not prepared to ask my Department to divert staff from existing priorities.

(2)â(5) Some information concerning research undertaken by my Department since 3 March 1996 is available in the Department of Health and Family Services' Annual Report for 1996-97 which was tabled in October 1997.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 17 April 1998:

question.para: (1) What was the system used for providing legal aid for veterans' appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) prior to 1 July 1997.
(2) How has the system been changed since 1 July 1997.
(3) Is the Attorney-General satisfied that the amount of legal aid now available for veterans' appeals to the AAT allow legal practitioners to conduct sound cases for veterans.

talk.start.para: âThe Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) A special legal aid scheme for war veterans was established by the Commonwealth to enable war veterans with eligible or operational war service, or their next of kin, to have access to legal aid which is means test-free, in order to pursue reviews of war-caused disability pension entitlement or assessment claims. This scheme was, and continues to be fully funded by the Commonwealth.

(2) Under the former legal aid agreements, legal aid commissions obtained reimbursement from the Commonwealth on a quarterly basis for war veterans matters they administered under this scheme. Under new legal aid funding arrangements war veterans funding is included in the global legal aid funding amount paid quarterly in advance to each commission.

(3) I am satisfied that the amount of legal aid under the new legal aid Agreement will enable eligible war veterans to obtain appropriate advice and representation to pursue their war-caused disability pension and assessment claims in the AAT.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade: Advertising
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1150)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on April 23:

question.para: (1) What is the value of advertising placed by (a) the department; and (b) agencies within the Minister's portfolio, on a month-by-month basis since March 1996.

(2) What proportion of advertising placed by the department or portfolio agencies since March 1996 has been for: (a) print media; (b) radio; (c) television; or (d) other, and give details of other forms of advertising used.

(3) (a) What proportion of advertising placed by the department or portfolio agencies since March 1996 has been placed through the Office of Government Information and Advertising (OGIA); and (b) what mechanism has been used for advertising not placed through OGIA.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Accounting systems do not permit provision of a comprehensive month-by-month breakdown of advertising expenditure for the department and portfolio agencies. The value of advertising placed by DFAT in Australia from Mar 96âMay 1998 is $210,718. The value of advertising placed by Austrade in Australia from March 1996âMay 1998 is $569,673. The value of advertising placed by AusAID in Australia for financial year 1995-96 was $198,234, and $307,245 for financial year 1996-97. AusAID advertising expenditure in financial year 1997-8 was $598,514 to the end of May 1998.
(2) All expenditure has been for print media advertising.

(3) With the exception of $5310 spent on newspaper and periodical advertising placed directly with the journals involved, all advertising by the department and portfolio agencies was placed through TMP Worldwide, (previously Neville Jeffress Advertising), which is the Commonwealth's master agency for non-campaign advertising, and which forms part of the central advertising system managed by OGIA.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Transport and Regional Development: Advertising
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1164)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 23 April 1998:

question.para: (1) What is the value of advertising placed by: (a) the department; and (b) agencies within the Minister's portfolio, on a month-by-month basis since March 1996.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: 1 The Commonwealth is in the process of selling the above-rail operations of the Australian National Railways Commission and transferring rail infrastructure into the recently-established Australian Rail Track Corporation. The process has left AN with insufficient resources with which to provide the level of detail sought by the Parliamentary Question, nor in the case of the above-rail operations, ready to access material from which to draw the data. Bankstown Airport has participated in local sponsorship programs such as Remembrance Day and Constable Care.
Other forms of advertising were flyers and leaflets, Variable Message Signs, Convenience Ads (Drink Driving), Cinema and a Web Site, and advertising in AGPS Special and General Gazettes.
(3) (a) The Federal Office of Road Safety placed $2,772,238.06 or 98% of advertising through OGIA. No other departmental and portfolio advertising was placed through OGIA.

(b) The mechanisms for placement of advertising not through the OGIA were placement by PPK Environment & Infrastructure, direct contact with media supplier, the engagement of contractor to design a web site, placement through TPM World Wide Company (formerly trading as Neville Jeffressâan OGIA-endorsed supplier), placement through Executive Media Pty Ltd, placement through the Government's contracted agencies for non-campaign press advertising, gazette notices placed direct with AGPS, and placement direct with media sources.

talk.start.para: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 27 April 1998:

question.para: (1) When was the Government Members Secretariat established.

(2) (a) How many employees did the secretariat have at that time; (b) were all positions at the secretariat advertised; if so, when and where were advertisements placed; (c) what position did each employee hold; and (d) what salary range applied to each position.
(3) (a) What salary level applied to each employee at the time of his or her appointment; (b) how was that salary level determined; and (c) by whom was it determined.

(4) (a) How many appointments have been made to the secretariat since it was established; (b) were the positions advertised; (c) when were the appointments made; (d) what salary range applied to any new appointments; (e) what actual salary was applied within that range; (f) who determined the actual salary level applied; and (g) are all employees based in Canberra.

(5) (a) Have all secretariat employees always been located in Canberra; if not, where were they located; (b) how long were they located there; (c) were they paid any special allowances; (d) to what did those special allowances relate; and (e) how long were they paid.
(6) (a) What variations have occurred to salaries paid since the appointment of each employee; (b) when did those variations occur; and (c) what was the basis for the variation.
(7) (a) How many employees have left the secretariat since it was established; (b) when did they leave; and (c) why did they leave.

(8) (a) How many employees have a mobile phone, a computer or a motor vehicle provided by the Government; and (b) what percentage of the costs associated with this equipment and motor vehicles is met by the Government and what percentage is met by the employee.

(9) (a) How much money has been spent on renovations or refits to the secretariat office in Parliament House since March 1996; (b) what was the exact nature of the work undertaken; (c) when did it commence and what was the completion date; and (d) were tenders called for the work.

(10) (a) How much money has been spent on equipment for the secretariat since March 1996; (b) what are the details of the equipment purchased; (c) when was it purchased; and (d) were tenders called for the supply of equipment; if not, why not.
(11) Why was the equipment purchased by the secretariat.

(12) Is any of the equipment located in a place other than the secretariat's Parliament House office; if so: (a) what equipment is located outside the office; (b) where is the equipment located; and (c) why is it at that location.
(13) How much money has been spent on stationary, by month, by the secretariat since March 1996.

(14) (a) How much travel has been undertaken by secretariat employees since March 1996; (b) which officers travelled; (c) where did they travel to; (d) when did they travel; and (e) what was the purpose of the travel.
(15) (a) What contracts have been let by, or on behalf of, the secretariat since March 1996; and (b)
which agency or agencies actually signed the contracts.

(16) (a) Which of the contracts in (15) related exclusively to the operation of the secretariat; and (b) which contracts related in part to the operation of the secretariat and in part to the operation of other agencies or departments.
(17) Where the value of a contract was allocated between the secretariat and another agency or department, to what extent did the secretariat benefit from the contract.
(18) (a) What was the value of each contract; (b) what was each contract for; and (c) were tenders called for each contract.
(19) (a) What consultancies have been let by, or on behalf of, the secretariat since March 1996; and (b) which agency or agencies actually signed the contracts.

(20) (a) Which of the consultancies in (19) related exclusively to the operation of the secretariat; and (b) which consultancies related in part to the operation of the secretariat and in part to the operation of other agencies or departments.
(21) Where a consultant was required to work for the secretariat as well as another agency or department, to what extent did the secretariat benefit from the consultancy.
(22) (a) What was the value of each consultancy; (b) what was each consultancy for; and (c) were tenders called for each consultancy; if not, why not.
