talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 28 April 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) What role did the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) have in the approval of an application from PowerBar Australia to import a sports food product; (b) when was that approval given; (c) what was the life of the approval; and (d) what was the scientific basis on which the approval was granted.

(2) (a) Did AQIS advise the above company on 22 January 1998 that a shipment of PowerBar products were being held at the docks because the product did not conform with any food standard; and (b) what changes occurred from the initial approvals by AQIS for PowerBar products to the blocking of the above shipment.
(3) (a) What role does AQIS have in the development of food standards; and (b) has AQIS been involved in the development of a sports food standard; if so, what was that role.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) AQIS has not issued an approval for PowerBar Australia to import a sports food product.

(2) (a) No; however AQIS did advise PowerBar Australia on 28 January 1998 that a shipment of product held at the importers did not comply with Standard S1 of the Food Standards Code. (b) There was no initial approval by AQIS.

(3) AQIS has the opportunity to comment to the Australia New Zealand Food Authority during the public comment phases of the development of food standards; as the details of the sports food standard did not directly impact on AQIS's core responsibilities AQIS had minimal input to the development of this standard.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 28 April 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the Australia New Zealand Food Authority (ANZFA) approve an application by a company called Power BarâAustralia to import a sports energy bar; if so, what analysis of the product was undertaken before its importation was approved.

(2) (a) When was approval granted and under what authority was permission given to import the bar; (b) was there a time limit placed on the approval; if so, what was the life of the approval and how was that determined; and (c) was the importer required to renew the permit; if so, how often was the renewal required and what process was the importer required to follow.

(3) (a) Has approval for the importation of the Power Bar been suspended; if so, when was that suspension imposed and what was the basis of the suspension; and (b) how long will this suspension remain in force.

(4) (a) Has ANZFA determined a standard for the importation of sports food products; if so: (i) when was the process of determining the standard commenced, (ii) what procedures were followed, and (iii) when was the standard finalised; and (b) if the development of such a standard is underway: (i) when did the process commence, (ii) at what stage is the process, and (iii) when does ANZFA expect the standard to be finalised.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) No, ANZFA did not and cannot approve food for importation into Australia. ANZFA develops food standards which are contained within the Australian Food Standards Code (FSC), and these food standards have effect through adoption by reference into States and Territory legislation.

The Imported Food Control Act 1992, which is administered by the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service (AQIS), also adopts the FSC by reference and this is the basis for inspection and clearance of imported food at the customs barrier.
As no application from PowerâBar Australia has been received to amend the FSC, ANZFA has no information on the analysis of this product.

(2) As ANZFA has no authority to approve foods for importation this question would be better directed to the AQIS. AQIS is responsible for assessing the compliance of imported food with the FSC and appropriate quarantine requirements.
(3) See answer two.

(4) No. However, ANZFA has recently gazetted a new food standardâStandard R10âFormulated Supplementary Sports Foods. The development of this standard was commenced in 1993. The standard was developed through ANZFA*s statutory processes which, in summary, it requires:
- a proposal to develop the standard to be raised by ANZFA;
- a round of public consultation;
- full assessment of the proposal by ANZFA, with an associated draft amendment to the Food Standards Code;
- a further round of public consultation;
- a recommendation from ANZFA to the Australia New Zealand Ministerial Council;
- gazettal and bringing into force of the amendment to the Food Standards Code.
Gazettal of this standard occurred in March 1998 and it came into force immediately.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 29 April 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister corresponded or communicated with the Western Australian Minister for the Environment, the Hon. Cheryl Edwardes, in relation to the Western Australian regional forest agree ment; if so, can copies be provided of the correspondence or communication.

(2) Has Environment Australia been involved in any correspondence or communication with any State or Federal Government department or minister, the Forest Industries Federation of Western Australia, Alcoa Australia, the Forest Protection Society, or Wesfarmers Limited or any of its subsidiaries including the Bunnings group of companies, Wesfarmers Bunnings Limited and Bunnings Forest Products Pty Ltd, in relation to the Western Australian regional forest agreement; if so, can copies be provided of that correspondence or communication.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. No copies can be provided as the correspondence relates to sensitive negotiations between the Commonwealth and the Western Australian Government in developing the Regional Forest Agreement in Western Australia.

(2) Yes. Environment Australia has corresponded and communicated with State and Federal Government departments and ministers, the Forest Industries Federation of Western Australia, Alcoa Australia, the Forest Protection Society, Wesfarmers Bunnings Limited and Bunnings Forest Products Pty Ltd, in relation to the Western Australian Regional Forest Agreement.

Copies of correspondence between Environment Australia and State and Federal Government departments and ministers cannot be released as these documents cover sensitive negotiations between the Commonwealth and the Western Australian Government in developing the Regional Forest Agreement in Western Australia.

Copies of correspondence between Environment Australia and the Forest Industries Federation of Western Australia, Alcoa Australia, the Forest Protection Society, Wesfarmers Bunnings Limited and Bunnings Forest Products Pty Ltd, in relation to the Western Australian Regional Forest Agreement, have been forwarded to the honourable senator. This correspondence dates from the signing of the Scoping Agreement for a Western Australian Regional Forest Agreement on 3 July 1996.
Further copies of the correspondence are available from the Senate Table Office.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 29 April 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) On what date was the jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Court transferred; and (b) to which body was the court's jurisdiction transferred.
(2) Were Industrial Relations Court judges transferred to another court; if so, which one; if not, what happened to those judges.
(3) How many:(a) Judicial Registrars; and (b) other staff, remain employed in their former positions with the Industrial Relations Court.
(4) What is the unexpired period of the contracts under which these staff remain employed.
(5) How many cases have been dealt with by the Court Registry since the transfer of jurisdiction.
(6) What is the total annual cost for the remaining Industrial Relations Court; (a) Judicial Registrars; (b) other staff; (c) accommodation; and (d) other costs.

talk.start.para: âThe Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (b) The jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Court was transferred to the Federal Court of Australia.
(2) All the judges of the Industrial Relations Court already held commissions as judges of the Federal Court of Australia.
(3) I am advised that as at 13 May 1998 there are:
(a) 13 Judicial Registrars (of which S are part-time); and (b) 17 former staff of the Industrial Relations Court now designated as employees of the Federal Court.

(4) I am advised that the terms of the Judicial Registrars expire on a number of different dates ranging from 26 July 1998 to 19 December 1999. 16 of the other 17 other staff are not employed under individual contracts, the other staff member is a statutory appointee whose term expires on 18 July 1999.

(5) I am advised that 379 cases were transferred to the Federal Court on 26 May 1997, 383 partially cleared cases remained with the Industrial Relations Court and 246 new cases have been filed with the Federal Court in the period 26 May 1997 to 8 May 1998. Of the total cases, 667 have been finalised and 341 are still current.

(6) I am advised that the total estimated expenditure in 1997-98 is $6,762,811: (a) salaries for judicial registrars $1,389,736; (b) salaries for other staff $905,387; (c) accommodation $1,286,000; (d) other costs $3,181,688.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 1 May 1998:

question.para: With reference to the 1992 national forest policy statement, and in particular to the commitments relating to wood production, wood products industry development and plantations:
(1) What legislation and/or delegated legislation has been passed and proclaimed, or gazetted, in order to implement the commitments referred to above.
(2) What government agencies have been established or persons employed to implement these commitments.
(3) What inquiries have been conducted by the Government in relation to these issues.
(4) What research projects have been conducted in relation to these issues.
(5) What Commonwealth funds have been provided for each item in paragraphs (2) to (4).

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The 1992 National Forest Policy Statement (NFPS) was endorsed by the Commonwealth and all State and Territory governments. It established an agreed framework for forest policy covering such areas as conservation, industry development, plantations, tourism and research and development. This was followed by a Wood and Paper Industry Strategy designed to encourage increased forest resources, investment, value adding and employment growth in the forest industries.
The current Government has pursued a deliberate and energetic forest policy, consistent with the

NFPS, which has included the development of Regional Forest Agreements; the endorsement of the Plantations 2020 Vision; a national Farm Forestry program including as an element of the Natural Heritage Trust; the development through international processes of criteria and indicators for sustainable forest management; support for an active program through the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation; implementation of a Forest Industry Structural Adjustment program and the establishment of a Wood and Paper Industry Forum.

Details on these policies, programs, research studies and legislation, and the financial support provided, are contained in Annual Reports, published project reports and other statements available to the Senate from my Department and other Commonwealth Departments involved, especially the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of the Environment and the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism.

talk.start.para: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 5 May 1998:

question.para: Can a list be provided of all employees, whether full-time, part-time or casual, of ministers/members/ senators who have received assistance for their studies over the period 1 January 1994 to the present, together with the aggregate total of that assistance; individual amounts are not required.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator Minchin
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: Under the studies assistance guidelines, an approved student may be reimbursed course fees upon successful completion of approved units. The names of the staff members who received assistance in the period concerned are shown against the financial year the payment was made. In some cases the fees relate to courses completed in a previous financial year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 12 May 1998:

question.para: With reference to the recently advertised positions on the Tobacco Research and Development Corporation (TRDC):
(1) How much Commonwealth money will the TRDC receive in the financial years 1998/99, 1999/2000, 2000/2001.
(2) What is the cost to the Commonwealth of administering the TRDC in each of these years.
(3) (a) Who is currently on the TRDC; and (b) what are its functions.
(4) What is the Commonwealth's policy on supporting and promoting the tobacco industry.
(5) How much money will be spent by the Department of Health and Family Services in each of the next 3 years on countering the impacts of smoking and running anti-tobacco campaigns.

(6) Why is the Commonwealth actively supporting the TRDC to carry out research and development for the tobacco industry, whose adverse impacts on health are imposing huge costs on the community and the Government.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Commonwealth provides matching, dollar for dollar, expenditure for the tobacco research and development levy up to a maximum of 0.5% of the gross value of production. It is estimated that Commonwealth expenditure in 1998/99 will be around $270,000 with similar amounts expected in the following 2 years. This compares with expected industry contributions in 1998/99 of around $660,000.
(2) The operations of the TRDC are funded from industry levies and the matching Commonwealth contribution. The Commonwealth does not make any direct contribution to the administration of the TRDC.

(3) (a) The Directors of the TRDC are Mr Eddie Gilbert, Mr Laurie Hunt, Mr Barry Dare and Mr Des Naughton. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Judith Troeth, is currently considering candidates for the appointment of a new Chairperson.

(b) The TRDC's core functions are to: investigate and evaluate R&D requirements; prepare five year strategic plans and annual operating plans for tobacco R&D; ensure R&D activities are consistent with TRDC plans; monitor and evaluate R&D progress; and facilitate the dissemination, adoption and commercialisation of R&D outcomes.

(4) In general, the Commonwealth provides assistance for primary industries R&D by matching, dollar for dollar, expenditure for industry research and development levies up to a maximum of 0.5% of the gross value of production. The broad objective of this policy is to develop competitive and sustainable rural industries.

The Government's dollar for dollar matching contribution is designed to provide an incentive for the primary sector to increase its R&D funding and to become more involved in R&D priority setting and the adoption of outcomes. This policy also recognises that activities funded by R&D Corporations generate a mix of public and private benefits.
The tobacco industry, which provides significant social benefits to the Mareeba and Myrtleford communities, is treated on the same basis as other industries.
(5) The Department of Health and Family Services has advised that:

The Public Health program includes a number of national strategies including the National Drug Strategy. Allocations under the National Drug Strategy cover all drugs including alcohol, tobacco and illicit drugs and it is not possible to provide a breakdown of specific allocations on a drug by drug basis as many of the initiatives funded under the National Drug Strategy do not relate to individual drugs but impact on the harm caused by drugs in general.

The Government has, however, announced in the recent Budget that it will allocate $6.1 million to tobacco harm minimisation activities over the next three years. Those funds will allow the National Tobacco Campaign to continue as well as implementation of a number of policy initiatives.
(6) As per question (4).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 13 May 1998:

question.para: With reference to the Australian drought assistance to West Papua:
(1) Was West Papua given top priority for assistance when the Australian Defence Force (ADF) first evaluated the need in 1997.
(2) Was West Papua subsequently downgraded by AusAID officials, as claimed in a Radio National interview; if so, when was this done; and why.
(3) Did Indonesian authorities such as the Irian Jaya Co-ordinating Bureau refuse ADF assistance when it was offered in 1997.
(4) What caused the 8-month delay in getting ADF personnel into West Papua.
(5) How many people are estimated to have died from the drought in West Papua.

talk.start.para: âThe Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: (1) In late 1997, staff at the Australian Embassy in Jakarta reported information from United Nations organisations, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and non-government organisations (NGOs) indicating that famine was causing deaths in the highlands of Irian Jaya. With the concurrence of the Government of Indonesia, the Australian Government immediately provided funds to support the relief effort being mounted by these agencies. There was no request at this stage from the Indonesian Government for ADF assistance and no ADF evaluation of the need was therefore conducted.

(2) AusAID officials did not downgrade the situation in Irian Jaya. As indicated above, once the extent of the problem became known, the Australian Government immediately provided $1.3 million for the relief operations of the United Nations Development Program (UNDP), ICRC and World Vision Australia. In January 1998, a further $2 million was provided to the ICRC emergency appeal.
(3) ADF assistance was not offered in 1997.

(4) ADF assistance with the relief effort was not offered until a Government to Government approach for assistance was received from Indonesia. In April 1998, Indonesia provided the first formal advice that they would accept an Australian offer of assistance with the relief operation. Following his discussions with the Indonesian Defence and Security Minister, Minister McLachlan announced on 15 April 1998 that Australia would increase its assistance to the humanitarian relief effort and this would include the use of ADF assets to increase airlift capacity. The first ADF personnel were deployed in early May 1998. This additional Australian assistance to Irian Jaya from the aid and defence budgets is expected to be worth up to $10 million.

(5) Official estimates indicate that at least 600 people may have died as a result of the drought conditions. However it is likely that some deaths in more remote villages have not been reported to the authorities. As well, the incidence of malaria has significantly increased as a result of displacement of populations with low natural immunity. Recent tests carried out by medical teams from the NGO, Medecins Sans Frontieres, indicate that the mortality rate may be as high as 30 deaths per 10,000 cases.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 13 May 1998:

question.para: (1)What are the current rules regarding the captioning of television programs so that deaf and hearing-impaired people can enjoy them.
(2) Is it the case that America and Britain have laws in place to ensure that programs are captioned.
(3) Will similar laws be introduced in Australia.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Under the self regulatory arrangements contained in the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, the broadcasting industry is encouraged to develop codes of practice which relate to the captioning of programs for the hearing impaired. Commercial free to air television broadcasters are responsible for deciding whether their programs are closed captioned, in accordance with the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations (FACTS) Commercial Television Code of Practice (the Code). The Code requires FACTS members to endeavour to increase the amount of closed cap tioned programming in consultation with organisations representing hearing-impaired and deaf viewers.

Open and subscription television narrowcasting services are covered by the relevant Australian Subscription Television and Radio Association (ASTRA) Codes of Practice, which require narrowcasters to identify captioned programs in their program schedule information, and to consult organisations representing hearing-impaired and deaf viewers when introducing or extending the provision of captioned programming. Codes for subscription television broadcasting (pay television) and community television are being developed.

There are currently no legislative requirements for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) or the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) to provide captioning of their television programming. However, the ABC is required by both its Code of Practice and Editorial Guidelines to endeavour to increase the amount of closed captioned programming as funds permit.

The Government has implemented other measures to increase the level of captioning on free to air television. In the 1996/97 Budget, the Government allocated $7 million over four years to caption the ABC and SBS early evening news services.
(2) Yes.

(3) The Government has recently announced its policy framework for the introduction of digital television broadcasting services in Australia. The Government will require existing commercial and national (ABC and SBS) free-to-air broadcasters to commence digital television services in metropolitan licence/coverage areas on 1 January 2001 and in regional areas from that date, so that digital transmission has commenced in all regional licence/coverage areas by 1 January 2004.

As part of its policy framework, the Government will require commercial and national free-to-air broadcasters to provide a closed captioning service for all prime time programming as well as for news and current affairs outside prime time.

Bills to give effect to the Government's decisions on digital television were introduced into the House of Representatives on 8 April 1998. Provisions in these Bills require the development of regulations to determine standards which are to be observed by commercial and national broadcasters for captioning of television programs transmitted in prime viewing hours and news and current affairs programs transmitted at other times.
The captioning standard will apply to both analog and digital transmission of television programs and
will come into effect from 1 January 2001 (the date of commencement of digital television services in Australia).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 12 May 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) Why has the National Greenhouse Advisory Panel (NGAP) not met since October 1997; (b) when is it next scheduled to meet; and (c) what is its ongoing role now that Australia has signed the Kyoto protocol.

(2) (a) What proportion of homes in Queensland, New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia, respectively, have solar hot water; (b) what quantity of greenhouse gas emissions would be saved if the proportion of homes with solar hot water in Queensland was increased to the level of Western Australia.
(3) What quantity of greenhouse gases will be emitted by the Nambour coal-fired power station planned as part of Queensland's Surat scheme.
(4) Will the Government require an assessment of this proposed power station under the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974

(5) Which `national environmental significance' criterion in the Government's proposed `reform' of environmental legislation would trigger Commonwealth involvement in the assessment of the Nambour power station.

(6) (a) How will the Commonwealth restrict increases in greenhouse gas emissions to the 8 per cent limit set by the Kyoto protocol; and (b) will the Commonwealth assess all projects with large scale emissions, including land clearing, or will it simply allow projects to proceed on a first-come first-served basis until the limit is reached.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (l) (a-c) The National Greenhouse Advisory Panel (NGAP) has made a valuable contribution to the National Greenhouse Strategy which is now being finalised by governments. A further meeting of NGAP is not currently scheduled. Following endorsement of the National Greenhouse Strategy NGAP may be reconstituted as a peak consultative council on greenhouse policy.
(2) (a) The most recently available data from ABS (June 1994) on domestic hot water systems shows the following percentages for the use of solar energy:

(2) (b) The extent of greenhouse gas emissions saved through the installation of a solar hot water system is dependant on a number of variables including the type of heating unit replaced and patterns of use. However, emissions savings in excess of 250,000 tonnes of CO2 per annum could be anticipated.

(3) The Nambour power station proposal has not been referred-to Government and I am not aware of the details of the planned power station. Emissions from the power station will among other factors depend on the type of coal used, the efficiency of the coal firing and steam raising process, and the size of the plant.
(4) Current Commonwealth legislation for environmental impact assessment only applies to proposals requiring a Commonwealth decision or action.

Projects within the Surat/Dawson region are subject to environmental impact assessment in accordance with Queensland legislation. Power station developments in the region have the potential for significant greenhouse emissions and greenhouse implications will be assessed by the State Government in accordance with State legislation. Any project proposal requiring Commonwealth decisions or actions will be examined under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.

(5) Current Commonwealth legislation for environmental impact assessment only applies to those proposals which require a Commonwealth decision. Reform of Commonwealth environmental legislation is currently underway and not yet finalised. However, it is not the intent of the Commonwealth to include greenhouse issues as a trigger for Commonwealth involvement in the assessment or approval of individual proposals.

(6) (a) The Government is committed to meeting the target for greenhouse gas emission reductions established under the Kyoto Protocol. The Australian Greenhouse Office (AGO) will evaluate progress towards the target and report to Government on a regular basis. The Government, through the AGO, is progressing towards full implementation of the package of measures, representing $180 million investment, announced in November 1997. The National Greenhouse Strategy is another important vehicle through which Australia's actions will be implemented and reported against. The Strategy is currently being finalised by the Commonwealth and the States and Territories.

(6) (b) The Government will address the Kyoto target through a broad range of measures, and will be evaluating progress towards the target on a regular basis. Projects with significant greenhouse gas emissions will be assessed by State governments in accordance with State legislation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 12 May 1998:

question.para: (1) Will the Minister order a full Commonwealth environment assessment of Queensland's Surat scheme, comprising coal mines, dams, power stations, irrigation, port development and dredging.

(2) Will the total impact of this integrated regional development on the World Heritage listed Great Barrier Reef, and on Australia's capacity to meet greenhouse gas reduction targets, be assessed; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Current Commonwealth legislation for environmental impact assessment only applies to proposals requiring a Commonwealth decision or action. No such decision or action is needed for the Surat/Dawson scheme as a whole. Decisions relating to specific projects, such as under the Commonwealth's foreign investment policy, may trigger assessment action under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 (Impact Act) for individual proposals.

(2) Projects within the Surat/Dawson region are subject to environmental impact assessment in accordance with Queensland requirements. I am concerned to ensure that impacts of projects on the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Property are fully considered and have written to the Queensland Minister for Natural Resources in regard to the Comet and Dawson Dam proposals.

Power station developments in the region have the potential for significant greenhouse emissions. Greenhouse implications will be assessed in accordance with State requirements. Those requir ing Commonwealth decisions or actions will be examined under the Impact Act.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 14 May 1998:

question.para: With reference to the answer to Senate question on notice no. 955 (Senate Hansard, 1 December 1997, p. 9969):
(1) With reference to paragraph 6(c): on which dates, and with whom, were the discussions between February and July 1997 held.

(2) With reference to paragraph 7(a): (a) Can any evidence and any report written to, or by, the Standards Review Panel of Tasmania by Dr Penelope Flett be provided; (b) specifically, what was unacceptable in the quality of care at Derwent Court and what suggested the proprietor's inability to understand how to adequately address the problems; and (c) who reviewed the decision and is that review available.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The discussions took place between Mr Stephen Dellar, then State Manager, Tasmania and the Chief Executive Officer of Southern Cross Homes Inc, Mr Richard Sadek as well as some board members. Some meetings also involved other senior staff of Southern Cross Homes. Discussions took place on the following dates: 5, 6 and 21 February 1997; 6, 7 and 13 March 1997; 28 April 1997; and 21 July 1997. The discussions on 6 and 7 March took place by telephone.

(2) (a) The Report of the Standards Review Panel of Tasmania was published and distributed by the Department on 21 July 1997. I am informed that a copy was delivered to the honourable senator's office in Hobart on 20 May 1998. As to the

evidence considered by the Panel, that is set out in the report. Insofar as some of the documents belong to the Commonwealth, the Department is willing to provide copies to the honourable senator at his request. Other documents considered by the Panel were the property of the service provider, Jadwan Pty. Limited, and it would not be appropriate for the Department to release those documents without the service provider's consent.

(2) (b) The matters raised in the question, namely complex factual issues which, for the most part, involve expert opinion are currently before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1977. It would therefore not be appropriate to comment. To the extent that these complex factual issues relate to a current action before the Federal Court of Australia, referred to in more detail in the response to the next part of the honourable senator's question, it would also not be appropriate to comment.

(2) (c) If, by this question, the honourable senator is referring to the decision of the delegate of the Minister to revoke the approval of the nursing home under section 44 of the National Health Act 1953 (the Act), that decision was reconsidered by Mr Robert Griew, State Manager, New South Wales of the Department of Health and Family Services as the delegate of the Minister for Family Services for the purposes of s.105AAB(4) of the Act. Mr Griew affirmed the decision to revoke the approval of the nursing home. Mr Griew's decision is currently the subject of an application for review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 and is to be considered by the Federal Court of Australia. It would therefore be inappropriate to comment.

If, however, the honourable senator is referring to the finding of the Standards Review Panel of Tasmania chaired by Dr Penelope Flett that the submissions of the proprietor would not result in sustainable improvements in the quality of care being provided, then that finding is not a reviewable decision within the terms of the National Health Act 1953.
